I get the frustration with ASUS messing things up when they send you free hardware.  I wish I had that problem - well the free part anyway.  So, I would say don't look a gift horse in the mouth and instead work with them to get it sorted out rather than flame them.    Look, when you overclock hardware, you are driving everything beyond design specifications.  This means more heat and more heat means shorter lifespans at the component level.  Just because devices can be overclocked doesn't mean that it is a good idea to do so and without adequate heat transfer mechanisms in place (proper thermal/electrical engineer level knowledge, not garage band style engineering is needed to be certain of this) then you will eventually damage your gear.  Blaming the failures on ANY motherboard manufacturer when you have been driving their hardware harder is not taking your contributions to the potential failure into account and that is dishonest IMO.  You said yourself that ASUS should not release a beta bios update if it has the potential to do real damage.  Well, what do you think you are doing when you tweak clocks, timing, impedances to get that last 1% speed increase?  You are literally doing the same thing that you say ASUS should not.  I am willing to bet that your motherboard failures can be traced back to over- heating related issues brought on by overclocking.  You can't get temperatures at every location on the system that could be a point of failure.  Heck, even traces can suffer heat related failure.  Each trace has its own impedance and impedance, contrary to many a youtube channel guru is NOT resistance. Impedance is comprised of resistance, capacitive reactance, and inductive reactance:  Impedance Z = R + j(2Ï€fL - 1/2Ï€fC).  WHY? Because everything has resistance, capacitance, and inductance.  Even resistance is different between DC and anything with frequency (read up on skin depth effect).  My point is that every trace on the motherboard that carries high frequency signals will have a difference total impedance when driven at different frequencies.  Do you think that everything other than the changes you are making will "just work the same way"?  Not a chance.  If you tweak your hardware, then you are always partly responsible for any failures you may encounter. Once you own that fact, you might have a different opinion when looking out past your own face.  Knowledge is power. Knowing less than enough puts one in a position to open mouth and insert foot.   I would be very interested in the statistics on how many motherboard, CPU, RAM failures occurred as a result of overclocking as opposed to stock use.  I am sure that would be a telling story and might shed some insight as to what all component manufacturers are dealing with.  You can't expect BMW to warrant your car if you jacked with the ECU to get more power and blew the engine. Ok now I am done.  Let the flamers flame but doing so will just show you fail to understand the points made above. - Cheers

it doesnt mean the board is fried however it does mean the cpu is not comunicating with the motherboard. in some cases if you try a different cpu it will work fine as in my case BUT i did have another z690 hero that did not work no matter a different cpu memory stick or gbu so i had to RMA that board to asus.  it seems to me that in some cases the board will stay bricked with a 00 qcode but in that case more then likely the board has phisical damage that may not be seen in other cases where changing the cpu does work that is a cpu to board comunication problem.  another error code is 55 also meaning cpu to board comunication problem but that is a lot easer to fix then the 00 qcode. also i just purchased a z790 hero board and after i got the board i installed it and boom i got the 00 qcode with that board to and to top it all off some of the high end intel cpu's like the I9 and some of the I7 cpu's are also failing on there part due to bios defauilt settings that can fry the cpu.  so to sum it all up we are spending big bucks and getting screwed by asus and intel. as far as my RMA of the z790 hero asus wrote me back and said it was my fauilt so it fell out of warrenty and i would have to buy a new board from them so as i stated before we the consumer are getting screwed and we all need to step up and put a stop to all this the consumer should boycott asus and intel untill they get it right and they should not be ripping us off with things like advanced RMA or dening our warrenty because of there failer to produce a product that fuctions as it should after all its our hard earned cash that lines there pockets.

Sounds like your build pc, had a bad batch board, thru the soldering process. Used to be the production  manager for an engineering company, using Rohs pcb's in many varied fields. 99.9% of the time, random faults were down to poor solder profile loaded into solder flow process, more often than not, pushing them thru too quickly, to keep up with their orders (used subcontractors to populate) Rohs solder process has a very, very narrow window of correct temps and time frames, which if not followed to the T, would see batch failure rates around 20 to 35% at best, far higher, the further these flow profiles are fiddled with. Have a look under a microscope, for cold soldering on the pcb's, as if you see it on visible components, you can 100% guarantee the BGA components Will have terrible joints. BTW  i left said company after CEO refused to bin bad batches, sent em off to the US market (after telling him they would most likely fail) then got blamed when they arrived atop 2 mountains in their forests ( were fire service comms devices!). Lets just say, our last meeting was not a quiet one!

Thank you so much Jay. I've done three custom builds so far since I got into being a PC hobbyist. And all three builds had ASUS mobos in them. However after researching everything that you are presenting here, and can confirm to be true, I congratulate Asus in saying, you lost my business.
TLDR: ASUS scammed thousands of customers through lies and deception, denying their own international in-warranty repair service.   To whoever reads this, ASUS screwed my hard back in 2019. They claimed to have an international warranty service for their laptops. In short, you could request in-warranty repair in one country regardless if you bought the laptop in another as long as both were found in the same region.   In my case, I bought an ASUS TUF laptop from amazon USA while living in Mexico. I did this SOLELY based on their claim of international warranty, both USA and Mexico are in the same region (North America), and they were even directly listed (alongside with Canada) to be eligible for international warranty.  Unfortunately, a couple months after buying the laptop it completely died, would not turn on NO MATTER WHAT. So I got a hold of ASUS Mexico and explained the situation, they told me they could do NOTHING about it and that I would have to deal with ASUS USA for that matter. At the same time, ASUS USA refused to RMA because the laptop was going to be shipped from Mexico. Even after DIRECTLY citing BOTH THEIR WARRANTY POLICIES, showing how BOTH listed this international warranty service policy, they denied it and played dumb. Never got my laptop fixed.
Looking back, I really wish I had seen this coming! About a year and a half ago, I put together a computer based on Jay's recommendation. Everything seemed fine until late January, when both the motherboard and CPU decided to call it quits. Luckily, Intel replaced the CPU in just 10 days, but ASUS, the motherboard manufacturer, wasn't as swift. They initially sent back the same defective board, claiming it was new. After sending it back again in March, I'm still waiting for a replacement here in April.  Just this week, they offered to send a board worth $150. Mine originally cost over $350, so I declined, hoping for a comparable or identical replacement. Frustrated with the ongoing ordeal, I even reached out to the President's office for assistance, receiving a response but still no board.  This computer is crucial for my business, so the delay has been incredibly frustrating. Suffice it to say, I won't be buying ASUS products again.  (I have included my email to the president office below, been a real nightmare.)  Ron  I am writing to express my extreme dissatisfaction with the handling of my recent support case involving a damaged ROG MAXIMUS XIII HERO motherboard, which is currently under warranty. My expectation of prompt and efficient service has been grossly undermined by the significant delays and inconsistent communication from your team.  In late January, I sent you my defective motherboard and after two weeks, I was informed that it was going to be replaced with a new board.  About a week later, I received the new motherboard, only to learn from my computer tech that it was the same defective motherboard I sent in the first place!  This is after hours of him working to get it fixed and then informed your board also destroyed my CPU which had to be replaced.  Then on March 25, 2024, I dispatched the defective motherboard to your service center for repair or replacement again, as per the guidelines outlined by ASUS Support. It has now been nearly three weeks since ASUS received the motherboard, far exceeding the promised timeframe of 7 to 10 days for resolution. This prolonged period of inactivity has caused substantial disruption to my business operations, resulting in significant financial losses and undue stress.  My frustration is compounded by the lack of transparency and consistency in the status updates provided by ASUS Support. Despite repeated inquiries, I have received generic, pre-written responses that offer no meaningful insight into the progress of my case. Furthermore, when attempting to check the status online, I have encountered conflicting information, with different links providing contradictory updates on whether the product is still undergoing diagnosis/repair or has progressed to the replacement stage.  This inconsistency and lack of clarity are wholly unacceptable, particularly given the critical nature of the device in question. As a business user, I rely heavily on my computer system for essential tasks, and the extended downtime has had a severe impact on my productivity and profitability. I expect ASUS, as a reputable provider of hardware solutions, to uphold the highest standards of customer service and professionalism.  I cannot believe you actually sent me back my original motherboard, stating to me it was replaced with a new one!  Therefore, I demand immediate action to expedite the resolution of my case and provide me with a clear timeline for the completion of repairs or the replacement of the motherboard. Additionally, I request transparent and accurate updates on the status of my product, delivered through personalized communication channels rather than generic responses.  Furthermore, I urge ASUS to review its internal processes and address any systemic issues that may be contributing to these delays and communication failures. It is imperative that steps are taken to prevent similar incidents in the future and restore trust in ASUS as a reliable service provider.  Failure to address these concerns promptly and satisfactorily will compel me to explore alternative avenues for resolution and escalate this matter to higher authorities. I trust that ASUS values its customers and reputation and will take swift and decisive action to rectify this situation.  I expect a prompt response to this complaint, detailing the actions being taken to resolve the issue and restore confidence in ASUS Support.  Sincerely,  Ron

I had to cram it in the slot between my GPU and CPU cooler. It barely fit in there. I now have it installed in the lowest PCI-E slot on this new mobo. I do love the new PCI-E release button on this new mobo. It's so much better than the old method that was a total pain to use. I also love my Asus TUF RTX 4090. It even came with a small anti-sag magnetic stick. I'm still a fan of their products. They do need to improve quality control a bit. Because Jan 2023 I decided to do a full upgrade to Ryzen 7000 and get a Rtx 4080, so I went ahead and ordered up an X670E from ASUS, and 6000mhz DDR5...  Back then the big thing going around the early adopters was Ram instability.  It was DDR5 RAM this, Ram that, every problem was Ram, and Samsung vs SkHynix chips and so on.  As well as the bios for the new 7000 series was still being updated multiple times per month.  SO!  I pretty much chalked my problems up to being the Ram was sub-par and Ryzen 7000 was still wonky causing issues.. and Issues I did have a plenty!  upon first start up of the system I would blue screen every 5 seconds or so, it was hell to just get the drivers installed so the computer would run more than 10 mins without a crash.  And I had severe audio issues, audio going in and out, and loud crackling noises as well as volume level at 10% was basically full blast, had random studdering issues on screen and in device manager missing devices so that it was absolute hell to figure out the drivers for the system because the computer was reporting back that devices were non-existent to the motherboard, when they were in fact hooked up or in the case of the wifi actually built in to the board.  I was able to get the systemm so it would run for about an hour at a time without crashing by running in limp mode basically, AMD eco mode and Ram turned down to 4800Mhz, it wasn't until a much later bios updated I flashed in around Fall time of 2023 that it finally became a useable computer, it is now stable.. HOWEVER the cavoite is, its running in AMD ECO Mode, and ram is stuck at 4800MHZ as well as the CPU voltage is always going over 1.5v even at idle.   But this is the best I can get it, any tweaking of the bios at all sets the computer back into a fit where the mouse starts glitching across the screen and games crash constantly.  Its unfortunate because I paid for more than what I'm getting, The Bio's version that I found works the most stable is V.1415  for X670E    I just built someone a computer yesterday also a Ryzen 7000 build on a X670E Aorus board from GigaByte!  paired with 6000Mhz ram and a AsRock 7900xtx, guess what?  Zero issues at all.. everything worked so flawlessly right out of the gate and is already overclocked and running 4k happily within temps.  The sad part is, this build cost a lot less than mine.  Moral of the story, I guess I'll try to save up money again to replace this board I'll try and swap for a GigaByte or MSI board seeing how well they've worked for me in other builds. 16:07 When I built my first ever PC over a decade ago I had to call ASUS to troubleshoot my system crashes. I thought it was the graphics card, which was an ASUS 6770. I was just a kid at the time. Didn't really know what lead to chase. The motherboard was PCIe 2.0 x16 and the card was PCIe 3.0 x16. As a part of my troubleshooting  I researched if that discrepancy could be a problem - it wasn't (or shouldn't have been) but really ran out of ideas. I called up ASUS support and I'm almost certain I got through to a well known technical rep (who at the time also made visits to other Youtubers when discussing ASUS technical aspects for their videos) who, proceeded to tell me that the graphics card being 3.0 and the motherboard being 2.0 was "a problem" and that they needed to be the same, otherwise it was my fault (indirectly) so, even though I was pretty sure that was BS at the time I just kind of went along with it to get my RMA. Why would someone who is a technical SME need to say that the PCIe standard was the problem when he, the technical "expert" himself, knows full well that it's highlighly unlikely a hard crash is a result of a PCIe spec discrepancy? Even back then being inexperienced I could sense the transfer of liability. Doubly worse looking back is his, and thus ASUS's, leveraging of "expertise" to decieve a customer genuinely looking for help. The condescension is still around I see. BTW, the cause of my crashes had nothing to do with the card. My Biostar board had a bad DIMM slot. No stick in slot, no crashes. Sticks in any other config? worked fine. Live and learn. Speak with your wallet. We purchase products not only for latent capability but also for the capacity for those manufacturers to support us should we need help. I've owned many ASUS products, from the Zephyrus gen 1 and 2 to motherboards - when something (like a bezel panel arriving warped) needs to be fixed, they're outright incapable of repair. Need to reset your laptop and get a driver that was on the original OS? They wont provide it if you initiate a wipe. Now with their boards being so overpriced, it's just not worth it. I'm not getting anything I cant get from another brand, and it's not like it can get worse.

Well I'm just now seeing this.. On the topic of anti-consumer, I recently purchased and installed the Cooler Master MasterLiquid ML360 Illusion as well as six Cooler Master MasterFan MF120 Halo 3n1Fans to match what came with the rad. Well on the pump on the side it has a sticker over a tiny hole that says if removed the warranty is void, as well as the six purchased fans having stickers on the cables saying the same nonsense, which when getting to me two had already been mostly torn. Coolermaster was my first choice for AIO back in the day when I built my first PC. I loved them so much they were my first chair too. Now getting these I feel like as a customer I have no consideration. The pump sticker one takes away from visual aesthetics, and two I know overtime its going to be heated and warped or have the epoxy begin to run downward toward my board. Will it be conductive and short things, no I don't believe so from what I know about epoxy and how it's used to protect boards. But will it eventually slide, collect dust, and void the warranty that relies on the location of a sticker? Absolutely. The fan cables is what really gets me though because of the time it took to route them without tearing a single sticker was infuriating. I've been working with electronics for years, doing board, and cable repairs while I was in the Navy so I have a bit more practice than the standard consumer facing these issues. This seems predatory and unfair. I can't imagine some kid saving all their money to build a PC, ripping off a sticker, turning it on and having a dead fan to only be told it's no longer covered by a warranty. @Jayztwocents

Idk if that is extremely poor design or poor quality control but for a $900 chair either way is an absolute nono, and that really soured my taste with Asus. We often choose to buy a particular brand over others due to its perceived superior performance, quality, and support. As consumers, we understand that our resources are limited, and we don't have the financial flexibility to keep replacing or upgrading parts on a regular basis. It's part of what watching you guys do on line with parts we may own or aspire to own one day is about.  When we invest in a brand known for its high performance and quality, we are essentially making a long-term commitment. We do so with the confidence that our purchase will withstand the test of time, reducing the need for frequent replacements. This not only saves us money in the long run but also ensures that we can rely on our purchase for years to come.  Moreover, the quality and support associated with a brand provide us with peace of mind. We know that if an issue does arise, the brand will stand by its product, offering assistance and solutions. This reassurance further justifies our initial investment, making it a cost-effective choice in the grand scheme of things.  In a world where financial prudence is a significant concern for most consumers, choosing a brand based on its perceived superior performance, quality, and support is a smart decision that aligns with our need for durable, reliable, and cost-efficient products. I have been using hand-build development systems for myself now for about four years. I couldn't afford to step up to the thread ripper class, so I went Ryzen 9 12-core, and after a short flurry of missteps, I ended up with ROG Crosshair VIII Hero (WI-FI) 128GB-ram, 6TB-SSD. That system was very solid until I dropped the CPU on the floor. When I picked it up, I found the pin array was a mess. Two hours with a magnifier and a pair of tweezers (and many prayers answered) later, it went back into the socket (thank the Lord), and I never touched it again. That system was solid for about two years, and then I started having terrible peripheral problems I couldn't diagnose or live with. I decided to rebuild it with an Asus Intel-style board, using a fairly strong i7. I loaded up Ubuntu 22.04.2 and could never gain stability. It was one thing or another. After wasting a week of my own time fooling around with it, I returned the motherboard to Best Buy and switched to ASUS TUF GAMING X670E-PLUS WIFI. It is still not what I want. I am used to Linux(Unix) systems with uptimes that stagger the imagination. Under normal circumstances, there isn't a reason to reboot them. My system does strange things. I will come back to it, and the screen is black. The computer is still running, but the monitor says there is no signal. I can't shell in, I can't control-shift-F2. Suddenly after August patching the system seemed unstable like wifi not working reliably, so I reflashed the bios and removed the patch (which got reinstalled shortly after), and then I got the system stable again but I got an external wifi adapter as well to test.  Then yesterday, I got like 3 or 4 bluescreens in a row so I wondered what the hell is going on.  After that group of bluescreens, I got it up and saw that I only had 16 GB of memory vs 32 GB installed so I figured it's the ram (Kingston Fury Beast) so I removed the ram and reinstalled it swapping positions, and since yesterday it's been stable now. I've always been a big fan of ASUS products since I started building my own rigs over 20 years ago. But... Software and support have always been their Achilles Heel. I stopped using their graphics cards ages ago, as they would only update drivers at (long) sporadic intervals, whereas nVidia drivers were coming out frequently and reliably.  So, in order to keep up with the graphisc engine I would have to disable a lot of the proprietary ASUS software that came with the cards.  Just got a refurbished ASUS laptop (2021 model) and I can only hope it will last.  I'm already pretty disappointed at the state of their BIOS, it appears to be the "Special Ed" edition with pretty much NO adjustments the consumer can make. It's a ROG Zephyrus S17 (GX703HS), and there isn't even an option for performing a BIOS RAID setup, on a laptop which claims a 3TB SSD which is, in reality, three 1TB NvMe strips which aren't even RAID configured. Yes, I know Win 10 will let me configure a Software RAID, but my research has uncovered the fact that it's a less efficient setup that leaves a lot of storage unusable. Very sad that they've slipped this far. MSI, eh?

i thought i had a virus on my asus laptop. so i factory reset it multiple times and the temps were still insane. like 80c on idle, pushing 100c while gaming. i had just cleaned the fans recently also. so i thought it was a motherboard virus and took it to a repairman and he said there was no virus on it. so i was stumped and redownloaded all the software and temps were still outrageous. so finally i factory reset it for the last time and decided not to download ANY software. temps were normal on idle. so i thought and thought and before the only software i had downloaded was the ASUS ARMOURY CRATE. so i thought no no no, that cant be it, thats their own software that cant be the problem. so i downloaded it again to control my fans. BOOM temps shoot up like 30C on idle. even with fans up near 100% the temps were still near 80c on idle. i coulndt believe it. so factory reset it, DELETED ANYTHING TO DO WITH ARMOURY CRATE, and since then temps have been as good as they get for a laptop. now my temps are about 30c less and the fan doesnt sound even near 100%. so for a fact asus armoury crate is malignant software that ironically you download to control your fans, that makes your system heat up so much, that you need to turn up your fans. i have seen a handful of other people say they had other problems with armoury crate, and ive been posting this everywhere i can, hopefully to save someone from using armoury crate, or an asus product ever again.

Newegg was the distributor that I bought it from, so I put it down to maybe a Newegg issue, but now I'm not sure - maybe Asus's QC has been in decline since all the way back in 2016.

Brands I do not trust as a college educated IT specialist (+ brands that don't give a f- about you): HP, ACER, ASUS, ITconnect, Evolveo  I live in Czechia (gaming PC is *relatively* about 2-3 times as expensive for me than for you guys from western countries like US, France) and as a gamer from middle school I've bought an Acer Predator (noone in the family knew how to work nor even build a PC and I was like 15 so me neither), it's over  years old now and I've replaced the motherboard, original HDD, bought HDD, PSU, 3 RAM sticks. They've put a random-brand PSU into my system with no 80 Plus or anything like that, made in China (PRC, *not Taiwan)* and it killed my 80$ RAM kit, entire motherboard, both HDDs. Overvoltage killed almost everything and a nearest service guy said he thinks everything's dead. Luckily both CPU and GPU survived... without those I'd have no more money to spare and while still studying at a college, I do need a gaming PC for my assignments... The best part is when I reached out to ACER they *couldn't care less* cause I was out of warranty for like a few months (~2-6 months) already. I was told they no longer have any compatible MB and the support person couldn't even tell me the form factor of the MB (I was a high school kid, second year in high school, I was learning Intel CPU code names, *basics* of programming, trimming ethernet cables and just totally basic stuff, I had no idea what my PC even really is xD, figuratively speaking)  Right now I have an ASRock MB and (sadly) an Evolveo PSU (I got a great deal I couldn't let down but I will not have this PSU for more than 2 years, stuff I've experienced (2 dead phones, exploding batteries, overheating to like 50Â°C (yes, you can not hold a phone that hot, I am not even exaggerating) and seen on the internet and heard from peers is just too much but I have no money so it does have to do it's job for at least 2 years and then I'll buy at least an 80 plus Gold PSU)

@jayztwocents  I am beyond frustrated with Asus. The Z690 formula also has a major issue, which was originally falsely advertised and covered up by Asus (and/or EK?). I feel like this issue could use more visibility. My story is just one of many frustrated users.  I sent my Z690 formula in February to fix their corrosion issue, and they sent back a refurbished replacement a month later, claiming to have fixed a CPU socket problem (which they charged me for --- I didnt know any better). I had to follow up with 3 different reps before learning that they never touched the VRM; the "replacement" was not even ready. Luckily, they refunded me for the useless CPU socket repair. Over two months later they told me I could send it back for the VRM... I sent it in again, using that shitty white box I received. Somehow the PCB got major damage, and then they refused to fix it or cover it. I disputed and spent another 6 weeks going back and forth with the support rep. At one point, she told me they would cover it, but ultimately they didn't and stopped responding. They sent it back unrepaired and now I have a broken motherboard simply because I wanted to RMA in order to fix their original, non-copper VRM cooler.  I tried to buy a NEW replacement off Amazon (sold by Amazon/Asus). It showed up in a generic cardboard box packed in white foam. The box wasn't even the right size. The socket was missing the pin protector. The board had finger prints and was clearly used. None of the original equipment.
Literally just sent a B660 TUF motherboard back to RMA since I couldn't get a signal from my GPU  or motherboard regardless of hardware config, 2 monitors, DP or HDMI. My 10 year old ASUS motherboard maximus hero vi still working, but 1x EVGA GPU died and other GPU on way out, and recently PSU died (basically like a clock at 10 years). The MB always had crap driver/bios support... they didn't update it at all and come windows 10 upgrade problems started and all their software stopped working. The MB HW was good and only had to replace the coin battery. Just rebuilding the whole thing and going with a gigabyte MB...seems most reliable and the company getting more focused on enterprise rather than gaming. MSI would be second choice.   I used plenty of ASUS ROG stuff in the last 20 years...Software, customer service, and support was never good, though 10+ years ago their MBs were the top choice for performance, overclocking, and multiple graphics cards. I don't think it matters today because other brands offer the same BIOS tools and honestly overclocking isn't really a thing today...just like SLI/crossfire not needed. When shopping for MB today for AM5 build, my mine focus was low price and reliability...features or future proofing wasn't.   A B650 board for $150-200 good enough...add some expo 32g DDR5 RAM ($100), a 7800X3D CPU ($400) to match with a RX 7900 XT ($700), and reuse your PSU/case/fans/HDSs, you got a high end setup cheap considering 10 years ago I spent 3500+. Maybe I'm missing something, but I don't why anyone would go with an Intel/Nvidia built today...cost so much more for worse performance.

Asus aside, the whole rma to influencer argument is a 1st world problem if I ever heard it. The truth is the majority of returns of any motherboard, ram, or other internal component are due to novice builders buying incompatible products to their build and buyers remorse. That being said, sending a tested rma to review is wise and should be considered a gift horse.

Asrock has been my only board pretty much. It's annoying that people act as if they are all low quality. I had a 3820 and upgraded to a 3930k which I ran until Feb of this year. Overclocked both of them hard, never had an issue with x79 extreme 4m. For an HEDT board to have quad channel ram, a not so good VRM, and hold out at 4.7-4.9ghz on a 24/7 overclock for about a decade straight.... for $215 bucks, seems pretty good to me!  I got a Gigabyte board this time and while it works fine for being a cheaper z790 option, it notice it coil whines so bad. Louder than my old asrocks SBfan sometimes. I would have gone Asrock again but the feature set for these gen boards is so out of whack IMHO. I wasn't about to give up my indestructible backup ps2 periphs just because someone wants to spend my money on flashing RGB.
The x570 Tuf boards are problematic and you should never enable any auto overclocking or boosting because you will get crazy voltage and temp spikes. 3800x sits at 60 celcius then jumps to 80 in a millisecond then slowly back down to 60 then jump again. It cycles like that based on demand and you can hear the cpu fan cycle also. It never ever just hums it always cycles when gaming. Instead of overclocking a option to fix is to just cap the voltage in Ryzen Master. I have seen the voltage go up to 1.68v in software sensors as it cycles and that explains the 80 celcius jumps. What all this means is that anyone who just builds without overclocking is actually hurting their cpu more than setting a normal overclock because the cpu is constantly heating and cooling in cycles degrading the cpu quicker than constant steady temperatures.
So...should i avoid getting Asus rog ally?....

It even went up to 100Â°C several times. Because of the overheating it clocks down to 210MHz all the time. I've been using Asus products for a very long time. But it's painful to hear and deal with, first hand, the problems that have come up recently. My first personal computer (PC) was an Asus Laptop. My first desktop PC that I built had an ROG CODE motherboard for 7th gen intel. Now I've got a new Asus motherboard and I'm displeased immeasurably.  This laptop has been through thick and thin, dealt with an exhaust that could possibly burn my hand, dealt with several reinstallations of windows, it's on its second charger, the original battery after 9 years is completely dead, the original hard drive has several bad sectors that I had to use software to tell the HDD not to right or read from there, and yet it still turns on and works hard.  The motherboard for my first ever custom PC build stuck with me through everything I threw at it. I had all the cooling it could ever need and took whatever speed ram I wanted without complaint. I gamed on that thing day in and day out nearly every single day. Not once did I encounter an issue with it that I did not cause myself. It still works today. My buddy has it now and still uses it.  I am now the unhappy owner of an ASUS Prime Z690-P WiFi D4 motherboard. I had to dig through the bios to force it out of RAID so I could boot into windows and needed to scour the internet digging through forums about other Prime motherboards until I found a small thread that could help me figure that out. I have used this motherboard for nearly 1 year and the biggest problem that I have with this motherboard is that within 6 months of ownership, the motherboard had become unstable. What used to run perfectly at 3200mhz now has to run at 3000. While that sounds like a small problem, I have already swapped around the 4 sticks of memory that I have and have found that one of my dimms will cause the system to crash repeatedly. Windows repair can't fix it, reinstalling Windows with a 100% brand new install wouldn't fix it, clearing the CMOS and popping out the battery to make sure it was cleared wouldn't fix it, resetting it to factory state wouldn't fix it, upgrading and downgrading bios versions didn't fix it, but as long as that 1 dimm was not populated, the system would run perfectly fine at 3200, the rated speed for my Corsair RAM. I contacted ASUS after dropping the speed down to 2400 and they escalated and then promptly dropped me with a message telling me to lower my memory frequency. Are you joking? This is a brand new motherboard still within warrantee. Now I'm hearing all about these problems ASUS has been having and it's an absolute nightmare.  All I wanted was a reliable motherboard and I shelled out a lot of money to get one. My entire system costs a third of the price of my car and this took YEARS to save up for.  ASUS, if you're reading this, I either want my money back or a new motherboard. Anything else will not due. I don't want to be given the run around again, I don't want to have to wait weeks on end for a response, I don't want to have to dig into your own bios files to try and figure out what could be wrong, I want the product I paid for to perform as advertised. Otherwise, I will abandon you. I am the primary system builder for nearly all of my friends and I would normally recommend your products or even purchase them for them. Now, you've put a rift between me and you.

Actually, I've been having a bit of issue with Asus as well recently.  I purchased a ROG laptop from them.  I kept getting system lockup issues.  Not blue screens, nothing like that, the system would simply freeze up.  After making sure all my drivers were up to date, bios was correct, etc, and it STILL kept freezing up, I sent it to be 'fixed'.  I should have sent it directly back to Amazon and asked for my money back.  Though I said it was locking up, they decided their fix would be 're-install the OS and send it back to me.  Not only that, but their admin account was still in command, but 'disabled', so essentially I had no access to the computer.  I ended up re-installing the OS again myself.  Of course, this didn't fix things, and lockup/freezing issues continued to appear.  So, I sent it back to them AGAIN.  This time, I included a specific list of peripherals and programs I was using and had installed.  They sent it back to me with their repair form saying I had claimed the laptop was slow to boot windows, and that their fix was to...  RE-INSTALL!  Amazing!  It didn't fix a damn thing!  So, once it started freezing again after I got it back, I just said to hell with it and tried trading out some of the 'user serviceable' parts.  SHOCKER, I installed 32gb of corsair ram instead of the garbage they delivered it with, and wow, I haven't had it freeze once since!  I have MANY Asus products from the last decade or so, and have never had issues with them until this year.  And yes, the laptop might just be a fluke.  However, the way their service department treated the issue was not, and that has utterly put me off Asus, at least for the foreseeable future.   Something VERY wrong is going on there.

Savage
what a dumbass move.
I just came across this looking for something else. I may me able to help you with some of your issues of sound, mic dropping out, RAM issues etc. It seems that the ASUS Z590/Z690/Z790 boards all have similar issues which comes down to USB ports failing, resetting, only working if you unplug the device and re-plug it back in which is absolutely useless when it comes to using a powered external USB drive for backups if you have to keep leaving the drive unplugged until you get into Windows 10/11.  For the most part, the main issues with the USB ports are the PD firmware, voltage set manually and the ASUS Armoury Crate (AAC). With AAC installed it seems to do weird things to the USB ports and when you have certain devices plugged in, they either stutter, fail or stop working after a reboot and the current fix is to unplug the device un re-plug it back in. Some devices still fail after a reboot and freeze the system up until unplugged and then plugged in again. In my case it was an external powered USB drive for backups doing this which would even let you reboot the computer until you unplugged the drive.   Try this one thing to start with; use the uninstall tool for AAC and reboot you computer. Most of your issues with disappear in that one item being removed. Make sure you have the latest BIOS, PD Firmware and ME installed. My motherboard PCH voltage starts at 1.8v and goes to 2.1v so to give the USB a little more power. I just set it to 1.9v as the intervals are 0.1v. Also changing the fast boot to disabled is recommended to help recognise every device each boot which in reality adds 1-2 seconds tops. With the build I'm fixing at the moment it has over 6000Mb/s transfer with the new m.2 drives anyway so I'm still in windows within 10 seconds so it's no big deal.  People have said in other boards there default setting for PCH is 1.82v and max is 1.9v so they have set it to 1.87v but have found the PCH section on the board gets too hot. So for them it was stability with the USB ports and too much heat which caused a problem eventually or instability and heat within tolerance. Some people found moving certain devices to certain ports fixed the issues as the power delivery was evened out more. A good utility to use is USBDeview which tells you how much power usage is being used and also which ports and controller are being used and what devices were even previously used to help with moving devices. You will also need to use device manage with device by connection view so you can also see what controller has what device plugged in which will help with splitting the loads. This can also help with plugging in USB port multipliers and it is recommended getting powered ones to help reduced the power draw on the original port as power is a big issue and causes port resets etc which then drops off things like cameras, microphones, keyboards etc.  Then we hit the RAM issue. 2 sticks plugged in seem to work fine with or without XMP enabled. plugging in 4 sticks seems to create the initial issue for some reason. Again, make sure the firmware on all RAM sticks are the same as that will cause issues and BSOD. Then you can set XMP on but sometimes with heavy loads or large file copies, you will get the BSOD. It looks like when setting the XMP profile to on, it changes the settings and voltages but the voltage doesn't always go from the default of 1.2v to 1.35v for example even though it says it does. Monitoring software in windows will show it is 1.2v still for some reason so after you have set XMP on, also hard set the DRAM Voltage to whatever it is meant to be manually. In my case it is 1.35v but if you see in the monitoring software that the volts are say 1.34v, just up the voltage in the bios to 1.36v for example and make sure that the voltage is actually 1.35v or whatever your RAM is meant to be.   I then also tried installing USB PCI-E controller cards but they would be seen in the BIOS but not in Windows 10/11. Both controllers were ASMedia chipsets and they needed firmware updates to be seen properly in the newer z690 and z790 motherboards and then presented as hardware in Windows 10/11. You need to plug the card into older machines and use the ASMedia Firmware update tool for the chipset on the cards. I had 2 cards and one had an 1142 chip and the other had a 3142 chip. Finding the ASMedia firmware update tool was easy enough but finding the latest firmware for each card was not so easy. I did find both in the end and updated the firmware and then both cards are now also visible in Windows 10/11 to also help spread the load of USB peripheral's. If you need help with these tools and firmware files, send  me a message.  It's still very early days but I believe the USB issues are now sorted but I am still testing the RAM settings and things like loading the PC up and massive file transfer's before I am satisfied that the issues are now resolved. I hope this helps with your issues and resolves them too. So far, So good but I have lots of tests to run but confident I have sorted out most things now and hopefully everything once I have completed all my testing.

TLDR = Long time OC-er, use to be greatest Asus Fanboy. I've quit Asus long ago when they started making 4 phase double components VRM's and calling them 8 Phase and calling them great while they were not. Especially charging a Premium price for those designs while other companies have offered true 12 phase designs for same money.      Bit about me. Skip to next part for my Asus history. Well I am 52 yeas old with decades in the PC hardware. My background was electronics and when first Spectrum and Commodore computers came out I was hooked as the user. My HiFi and electronics knowledge helped me with the Commodore head adjustment and many other things :)  Early 90's I have started to work for IBM Germany and soon I was putting PC's together for the people in the office to buy them from the company. Like when there were non used hardware it was possible to sell it for a nice price to a people from the department. That was a time where people have had 286 machines and latter on 386 and 486. When Pentium came out I have moved to the Amsterdam Netherlands and I have left the IBM. By that time I was building and fixing PC's, making networks for small companies and fixed any issues people have had from printing to ergonomics at their working stations. I was building custom servers and working stations for design studio and video production. That was a time of Pentium Pro mind you. First Fast DV video editing card in Europe was ordered by me and that Company have had first editing solution for DV in Europe. Sony DV cameras have reached broadcast quality and were so portable compering to Pro Beta's.  So yeah when Asus came out I remember being it cheap option and just an average far east supplier with a big appetite. Back then in local shops choices were not that great. It was more what is in with the chipset and socket you want/need than what brand you choose. You would take what there is, build a system and then spend a day testing it before you give it to the clients. Torture testing everything you could. For me Asus became reliable solution even when their boards were not as advanced as some other once. They would just work. Asus availability became very good and their offerings started to go towards high end still keeping low cost and middle cost solutions. They were offering a lot of products and they were reliable and available. At one moment I was building all machines exclusively with Asus mainboards.  I was always running two rigs with newest and best there is. One Intel and one AMD rig. As soo nas something new would be out I was selling my things and building new. I was into OC-ing and extreme cooling. My first water-cooling setups were with Danger  Den water blocks and heater cores and Enheim aquarium pumps. I still have Asatek Vapochill case with a fridge at home. I use to get pure copper and make my own cooler prototypes. One hybrid CPU cooler that was half TEC half Air Cooled was featured as news on HardOCP web page. That was before anyone else thought about it. Half year after it Coolermaster  made their version. When Asus came with graphic cards I was on the board and having good experience. When they came out with Laptops I got some inside news and soon I have started getting them for my clients. They were great to. So yeah I was Asus fan number 1.  Even when they started charging arm and the leg for their mainboards I was in. Twice more expensive then Some other top brands = who cares give me Asus. Before it got popular to count phases of the VRM I was deciding what board to get by VRM design and cooling. That is due to my electronics background. OC-ing back then was requiring nice amount of clean power to CPU. When Cases where all beige color and no windows and just one single 80mm exhaust or intake fan spot and PCU was 200 Watt I was running 450 Watt Enermax PSU with two fans. I Was cutting out windows in the side of the case and using 12V car inspection neon lights and was cutting holes with a jigsaw and installing 12cm fans in those cases. Window and light was not for looks but to see is everything was still at it's place once you bring your PC to a LAN Party. I was painting my cases and making ducts before there was anything you could buy with a window and in any color.  Anyhow with i9 9900K I have discarded Gigabyte as well. Their default core voltage on stock settings was melting CPU even on huge water cooling setup. Went with MSI and getting MSI mainboards nowadays. I see trend for all brands to give to high default core voltage to make sure that top CPU models run stable. This is resulting in the wasteful heat production and no performance gain. Sure it is not as bad as few first BIOS generation of the Gigabyte mainboards for i9 9900K but it is often even 0,2 V higher than necessary when you have good cooling system.  Nowadays I think all mainboards are way overpriced and they lack even basic features and still demand ridiculous prices. Like till you get LED code indicators and hardware switches on the board you need to pay 500 bucks for the mainboard?? That was on every 200 bucks mainboard just few years ago. We live in the times when Companies can do what ever they want, charge what ever they want and people just accept it. Like current energy prices and prices in general. Here in the Europe it became ridiculous and still people take it. Food is twice more expensive, my energy bill went from 130 to 370 bucks per month. I thought there would be an revolution and heads would roll for that and nothing really happens. Even those companies started reverting the energy prices before people rebelled.  Asus needs to reinvent them self. They did it once when they were starting their saga. Can they do it now?

I make no judgement on the video and Jay's decision, except to say that there's no such thing as "Freedom of Information Act" (FOIA) as it relates to ASUS and Jay or whatever. FOIA refers to US governmental openness relative to its citizenry and disclosing documents related to governmental functions. A private company is not impacted by FOIA one way or the other, and a customer of that company could not exercise a so-called FOIA claim on a company. FOIA has absolutely nothing to do with a private business. Thus, I don't understand what he's saying. Still upvoted.
MSI boards have always been better than Asus and less expensive

Sounds more like my experiences with MSI products.  Between my B450-A motherboard and my wife's MSI laptop, I'll never touch their products again.  The hardware is substandard  and their "support" wavers between gross incompetence to sheer arrogance.  I had bought that board because it met my particular desired specifications, but the USB is flaky at best (sometimes not even recognizing devices on USB3), pushing out BIOS updates that **FORCE** enabling (IN)Secure Boot on my Linux system, their Dragon utilities on my wife's computer that caused major stability and overheating problems on my wife's MSWin10 laptop (merely scrubbing that product off, without any other changes cleared up nearly all the problems there that weren't caused by crap hardware design).  Even the internal USB connections seem garbage, and an internal memory card reader on the desktop system is just as likely to not see any cards that are readily recognized elsewhere.  So from what you're saying, I should be looking at ASRock boards next.  Board colors don't matter to me as I never use window cases.  My current primary system uses an old IBM X3200 server case, with two optical drives and 4 HDD bays (front accessible).  It seems modern case manufacturers think you shouldn't have external drive bays anymore (to which I say why should I even buy a mid or full tower case then). It's a pattern, isn't it. The same story, every time. Brand builds itself to be highly respected and recommended due to the quality of their hardware and/or support.  At some point, someone - probably a suit in some office who's never stood closer than 10 feet from a motherboard, nevermind handled one - decides  "you know... we're just not making enough money, still. We need to make more. What? We can't make more without sacrificing the quality that got us here? Well, then it's an easy solution.. Start cutting corners. Reduce the quality. Just make it look cool, and let our name and previous reputation sell the product".  And at some point, inevitably... something like this happens. And then the company pretends to be all "surprise pikachu face", "We don't know how this happened! This is most regrettable!! We promise to do better! In the meantime, please keep buying our product!"  And what does it boil down to? Greed. It's always greed. Because no matter how much $$$ they make, it's never enough. They demand more, even if it means burning the very customer-base who got them where they are. Because all the suits/shareholders know, or pay attention to, or care about is how much of a raise they can give themselves this year.
I've had the same realizations since buying some Asus BS back in 2020 and having headaches with them still until this day. They're gone for me.

I'm seriously starting to think this stuff is related to something a lot bigger and more malicious than greedy manufacturers and declining customer service. There are a lot of products that are no longer being made, products being made to die in short timeframes but past warranty, and cutting of support across the board. Some of this from companies who have built their reputation on supporting their customers. Considering the JIT business models and increase in floating credit lines etc. needed to manage to stay in a relevant market position, I don't think these companies are doing this of their own volition. I see a lot of odd changes going on in unexpected places in multiple industries and a lot of it seems to be coming from the financial side of things in ways that are beyond cost cutting or marketing screw ups like we've all grown accustomed to. I'm trying not to get into conspiracy theories but now that it's affecting people I know in my own industry its hard not to see it.

Are you sure you aren't putting a power supply on it that the mobo is not rated for? AMD doesn't over-volt their CPUs; although you can change those settings in Adrenaline under Tuning. It could be Wattman doing it, which there was/is a known bug in the software. I've been in this since 1989, never head of this, nor is it a thing. I work in the federal government in literally the biggest enterprise environment in the nation. I worked with a kid that was so stupid he tried to mount the mother board straight to the chassis without any stand-offs screwed in first. Told him over and over and he fried that motherboard... He tried to say it was ASUS! LMFAO! If you put stuff in your system that they explicitly don't recommend then when it burns out it is your fault.  Everyone getting 1500+ watt power supplies on motherboards that recommend no higher than 800 watts. I literally get no guff from any of my AMD products nor the ones I run at work. The Intel based computers constantly are an issue, especially with overheating. We get more problems with the cheap cooling they put in laptops now. I'm not buying a little amount like dude in the video... We're literally buying in the billions of dollars worth at a time. Intel lost me mostly when they started locking their multipliers and CPU registers. There are features in your Intel and AMD CPUs that the manufacturers disable and enable between models. For example, back in the day a 486 and 586 CPU could run Pentium instruction sets, but the feature was disabled. There was a utility you could use that would change the CPU registers to enable the disabled features, so you could run a program dependent on a Pentium with a 486DX CPU with no issues.

Im never buying from them ever again nor recomend anything they make, just like with Realtek, if you see a crab on your computer chips, it's likely a bug/failure about to happen, they have a even longer trackrecord then ASUS of making cheap trash hardware that is bound to only function if it's forcefully integrated into the motherboard, and even then i would question it's viability and quality, to me it seems Realtek's attitude is "our customers are to dumb to notice that it's trash we salvaged from a less reputable brands trashbins".

Still sounds better than my dark pattern experience with LG. (I won't ever buy anything LG ever again, from fridges to phones) This Asus issue partly comes from the consumer shift from traditional retail to online purchasing. With traditional retail the retailers usually ended up on the hook if they stocked bad products, and if a manufacturer screwed up too bad they would loose the sales contract for a whole retail chain.  With the online thing the manufacturer usually just looses a single customer while still keeping the money for the completed purchase.

My budding doubts about ASUS began with the Maximus VIII series. The only board in VIII line not to have the M.2 SSD connector was Impact. Instead they used a completely out-of-place enterprise grade U.2 connector, severely crippling it's usefulness in SFF builds. Many decided to sit that one out, and wait for ASUS to come to their senses with the IX series. ASUS responded with an announcement that Maximus Impact would be discontinued due to declining interest in ITX boards; the wording made no attempt to recognize or address the poorly regarded design decision and popular discontent, instead it portrayed the platform as a dying fad. Looking back at it, I believe they were already planning to cross the $1000 boundary with the Maximus product line and couldn't have an ITX board hanging along, so they knew perfectly well how to sabotage the sales just so they make a slim profit and make it look as if responding to demand.

Let's not forget their latest issue... on May 15th, they pushed out a corrupt server config file to their routers that broke internet/network connectivity over WiFi to thousands of customers (even those that had automatic updates disabled.) Within 10 minutes of the router booting up with that config file: it would run out of memory, and CPU usage on a single core would be pegged at 100%. Most media outlets didn't see or notice it, but as tech support for an ISP that serves several states...we certainly noticed it with hundreds of calls, from all ASUS router owners saying their internet is down and thinking it's an outage... Nope, the fiber is fine. Your router isn't though...  ASUS quietly in the news section of their website released an apology and fixed the issue on their end. But they caused a global outage for all of their routers for a solid 2 days. This not long after the whole motherboard fiasco.. ðŸ¤¦â€â™‚

glad to see the over volting addressed, i initially thought that the 13th gen chips just ran high voltage from the factory, until i tinkered with overclocking and realized otherwise.   not glad to see how they treat their consumers.  first thing i noticed when i fired up this 13700k build was that the asus z790-e gaming mobo was shooting 1.45v-1.7v into the chip at the stock 5.3ghz clock. tinkering with a few settings; MCE off, core clock, voltage, XMP on, c-states off, and SA voltage, i managed to hit a comfortable OC; 5.5ghz at 1.296v. not the best or worst chip, i def lost the silicon lottery, but my overclock lowered voltage and temps significantly and squeezed out 200mhz of performance from the chip.
Done, not buying any ASUS products ever... til they get their act together.

I have a Asus Strix GTX 970, 2 years after purchasing it their GPU Tweak software was trying to kill the card. How? Their software worked well for the first 2 years, then it would keep the RAM clock speed max but the GPU clock speed low when idle. So the RAM would be cooking because the GPU core was not heating up and the fans were running slow. Removing their software and using MSI Afterburner, the card never had this problem again and still running.
They failed me 1 time 20 years ago. I never went back.
Thier quality was gone 20 years ago :) lol

This is he which received seed by the way side. 20 But he that received the seed into stony places, the same is he that heareth the word, and anon with joy receiveth it; 21 Yet hath he not root in himself, but dureth for a while: for when tribulation or persecution ariseth because of the word, by and by he is offended. 22 He also that received seed among the thorns is he that heareth the word; and the care of this world, and the deceitfulness of riches, choke the word, and he becometh unfruitful. 23 But he that received seed into the good ground is he that heareth the word, and understandeth it; which also beareth fruit, and bringeth forth, some an hundredfold, some sixty, some thirty.

Jay, what really bothers me is the fact that this was ignored for so long.  Some of us have been talking about this for YEARS.  We were accused of damaging the boards, of not installing correctly and of just being ignorant, this is not just a hardware vendor issue.  Let me give a perfect example.  When I retired in 2019 I wanted to enjoy retirement and Asus had just released their 30th Anniversary Edition 30 X299.  Since I had been an Asus customer for almost that long it seemed like a perfect fit. Except it wasn't.  This system was supposed to support 256mb of RAM with its eight DIMM slots.  Except it didn't.  They didn't have a single supported configuration that would support it.  After spending 12 hours on the phone they told me they were working on it.  Well it's 4 years later and they still don't support it.  The also loved to play "bait and switch," by having the support techs keep changing mid call and then making you go back and forth on the issue.  But the final straw was being told that the board I bought COULD NOT BE SUPPORTED and they couldn't tell me anything about it because it had the wrong country code on the board.  Apparently, the board was supposed to be shipped to another country but ended up at my local Micro Center and by the time this was discovered you could no longer get these boards (unless you wanted triple the cost on eBay - if you could find one).  So, I have a very nice looking computer, that only supports a few banks of RAM (reluctantly), no chance of the QVL being upgraded.   Did I mention that when I went to get a replacement it was the Asus Hero that was recalled? What really bugs me is I have an Asus Z87 Sabertooth that I purchased well over a decade ago.  It sits in my garage (unheated/not airconditioned) running 24/7 in an old Lian-Li P80 case and the damn thing won't die.  My kids and grandkids log into it because I use it as a plex server.  To say I was loyal to the brand should go without saying.  But after the last few experiences with Asus I'm thinking about seeing what Dell has. I know this is long but Microsoft is just as bad when it comes to Windows 11 support on any of these machines.  It's hard to tell where the hardware is failing or the operating system is failing.  At almost 70 do I really have to start using Acer, Asrock and Linux mint?

I"M DONE WITH ASUS as well! I had a ROG Strix B550-F motherboard I put together w/a 5950X - my first AMD build that started having issues with the ethernet connection (YouTube, Spotify etc.,) would just stop playing for 10-30secs or so; YT would play reliable at 144p otherwise same thing, BUT playing same things in Windows Sandbox or on a virtual machine would PLAY FINE wtf??  I finally gave up and spent another $180 to replace that mobo with the newer B550-F WiFi version - after getting that put in w/drivers and bios updated - SAME ISSUE!  At first I thought it was Verizon FIOS throttling YT and other major streaming sites (they're still suspect, but that's another issue), but when connecting to my WIFI network w/the new mobo, the streaming issues went totally away (which was the same w/all my laptops - no streaming issues on wifi!)  Finally doing a search on B550-F wifi ok, but ethernet issues return a post with others complaining about wired network issues (w/a different ASUS model mobo) - one HEROIC dude's post stated "putting in a cheap PCIe network card solved all my issues...  I decided to do similar, ordered a 2.5G network adapter card - received it yesterday, put it in my system, disabled the mobo network adapter and ALL MY WIRED INTERNET ISSUES ARE GONE!!  Nearly a YEAR dealing w/this issue, wasting time, money, and suffering with this networking issue to discover it's ASUS's JANK network adapter chipset and/or driver code!  How the Sandbox or VMs didn't have similar network issues I don't know but LAWD I finally resolved this plague of an issue!  Back in March I went to Microcenter and bought an ASUS ROG G614J laptop thinking I'll just give up being stuck in my office w/that desktop and have a bit more mobility.  But now I'm noticing that the left side speaker has a "twang" / distortion to it if the volume is just a bit too loud, like a screw is loose or the speaker itself has an issue w/the cone - of course when I started noticing it, my Microcenter return window had closed...  I'm DONE with ASUS - BY BYTCH!

Thanks Jay!  I came across this latest video of yours by accident.  I was experiencing a very slow restart issue (5+ minutes) after installing the latest Win 10 updates and was doing some Safe Mode/Clean Boot troubleshooting. I was going through the list of services I already had disabled, one of which was the Asus Com Service (atkexComSvc.exe) and doing some searching to see what this service actually did and why I had disabled it, I was led here.  I've been a system builder for a very long time, and I'm probably dating myself here but my go-to motherboard brand before switching to Asus was Abit before they quit making MBs and then went out of business.  I really liked a lot of the little extras Asus used to include with their product; shielded backplates, all of the cables you needed, SLI connectors and even a printed manual.  Now they have cut everything to the bone and there's not much to differentiate their MBs vs. any other manufacturer.  I've used multiple versions over the years but after seeing this my next build is going to be based on another brand.  Keep up the excellent work!

When making new software you make the ALPHA versions where the code is buggy and initial in-house tests are made. When those initial tests are made and PASSED, you make a public pre-release and call it BETA acknowledging the software MIGHT still have specific issues, but it has been pre-test so it won't do catastrophic damage. If you are making software and releasing to the public, which will void your hardware ongoing warranty while trying to fix a crisis, and the software update is not fixing the crisis problem and still has the potential catastrophic damage, then you are not helping and making things worse, even you can argue you are making a trap to exempt you from responsibility.  It's been many years I've not used ASUS since they focus on esthetics and brand name, not durability or resilience. So I'm not surprised this is happening. I'm surprised it took this long to happen.

I have to agree with you about ASRock and it's reputation of old and it's newer product lines. Last November I built myself a new PC (coming from an Intel 5th gen), after the long wait of crypto, scalping, supply chain, xmp profiles and distributor/vendor nonsense that just made it impossible to build a high end machine at a fair price. I opted for a 13900K with an ASRock Z790 LiveMixer motherboard and it's been perfect for me. I was a bit apprehensive about the board at first because there was so little information and reviews about it, I liked the funky look of the board and the overall feature set of what is essentially a lower tier priced board. It was lacking in the audio department but I intended to use an external sound card anyway and it has a built in port for an internal display which I liked from when I had seen one of Jay's videos about how to include one in a build. In summary, a great, lower cost, stable board with plenty of features to use with the Z790 chipset. I am very happy with ASRocks product which worked as you would expect right out of the box, I think a company who has turned its reputation around deserves full credit and for those that abuse their reputation should be called out and made to suffer for it.

BTW, I know exactly why people destroy that, because those covers are terribly designed and it's not obvious if you should put it from inside ot outside, this is very often problem that people damages it while trying to close socket and cover it like before but they don't know how to put that cover there. It's fault of manufacturers and they are doing nothing to prevent these ridiculous mistakes. And it's even more ridiculous, people not such idiots, they do it because some older socket 775 boards really had that cover inside under metal lip, so people just put it there as they were used to and boom, socket destroyed. It's mainly fault of people who design sockets, they are stupid. Because of that, when I sell some MB with these LGA sockets, I am always puting big warning on a socket "don't remove it by hand, just close CPU there and it will pop-off" and "don't try to cover it back" because it just makes me crazy how many people will just instantly destroy that socket. 14:00 - I liked AsRock many years ago, I had some socket 478 board with intel 865 board, it was really cheap back in the day and totaly reliable and good MB, then I had AsRock with socket 1150 or what was that for Haswell and again, totaly reliable and stable board, no problems at all with AsRock.

I'm not advocating for any company here and I just wanted to share my experience with ASUS products. I build custom computers for clients, friends, and family. I've been building since I was 12 years old and have maybe 20+ builds on my belt.  I remember the introduction of the Nvidia 3000 series and many AIB brand GPU's were shipped with the wrong amount of MLCCs that were required by NVIDIA. The FE models came with six MLCCs and the only AIB GPU that was released with six was ASUS as I recall. This gives me a feeling of trust when it comes to quality control of ASUS GPU's at that time.   Having built on mostly ASUS motherboards, I really had not experienced any issues with BIOS or Driver issues except recently with a ASUS Z690-E WIFI BIOS update (Alpha) that I believe destroyed my motherboard (Reading is important if a beta BIOS voids the warranty do not use it). The RMA service was professional and had a turnaround of 1 week for my replacement motherboard. Although I believe the BIOS update was the culprit, I'm not able to confirm the cause and only informed ASUS what was relevant to RMA the motherboard.    On a side note, the IDPM design for the Z690 Intel 1700 socket is trash. I lowered my thermals by 10 degrees Celsius using a Thermal Grizzly Intel 12th Gen CPU Contact Frame.  With that said, I almost bought a Z690 Hero and was glad I didn't due to being a early adopter of the Z690 motherboards. I feel like Quality Control is getting worse TODAY, tomorrow is unknown to me. I don't hold much faith in Quality Control post, "Pandemic". I feel like the quality on everything has gotten worse since our country locked everything down and restricted people from working. It's 2023 and things are barely starting to get normal again. Hopefully quality control will get better in the future.  My Z690-E WIFI/i9 12900k is stable and working like a horse to this day.
This is a shame, I liked Asus as a brand. But after hearing about how shady they are, no longer am I a fan or will I recommend their products.
I gotta say, I had been using Asus for several iterations of PCs (and/or main components) I've used, and now I built a third last autumn and winter. And it will be the last one with ASUS, unless by the time I build a new one (which should ideally be some years in the future) they get their act together.  I've had no issues so far with my graphics card except for very annoying coil whine under load (but then I hear that's just normal with modern cards), but the first motherboard I bought was a Strix MB and it had a faulty ethernet chip. So I did some digging and found out, that chip had been known to be defective for years; Intel had done multiple revisions to fix the issue. But Asus refused to make sure they only used the newest generation of said chip (or another model altogether), so when buying any of these motherboards, you have a 1 in 3 chance of it being bad - possibly even higher. I got angry and spent more money on an even higher-end MB with two LAN and one Wifi chips (so redundancy would save me) but the news about Asus I've read and seen since makes me kinda angry about not having switched to, idk MSI or whoever is top dog next to Asus atm.  Also, some of their tools caused my system to freeze randomly in a very weird way. No clear trigger, just at some point the task bar would lock up, then the other apps one after another. Is a real pain if you're remote-connected to work trying to get things done. No fixes for that, just had to uninstall ASUS tools until the problem stopped occuring.   And I never got any customer support for either of those issues. They reimbursed me for the faulty main board, but only because Amazon has a strict return policy and puts customers first.
They will care when the Chapter 9 notice comes from the Board of directors.

I have a Asus ROG Strix X299-E Gaming II Mobo, its my second one and I have the Corsair Vengeance 256 GB ram kit max speed. My ram spikes are all over the place and I have had many weird issues with stability for GPU as well. What is a better board for the 256GB DDR4 kit I have? I have plenty of power with a 3080ti and a AX1600i PSU with the Intel i9-10980XE CPU.
And here I am using my ROG mainboard BECAUSE of its software. Say what you want but the firmware of Asus boards is top notch. Firmware updates are easy and do not require CPU/RAM installed and their UEFI support is also solid. Comparing this to the gigabyte board I had before (I would have had to run a program on windows before firmware updating in order to not brick my board) I NEVER want to go back. I cannot judge the windows drivers as I run Linux, but I have never had a problem since I have bought it.

I then bought the ASUS SimPro Dock because my laptop was from the generation without a MUX switch and I wanted to be able to use my graphics card with my HDMI gaming monitor to get max refresh rate out of it.. The dock is super slick and all, but it will sometimes have a problem where the second monitor just goes completeley black. It will still be there in my display settings, the windows on that monitor wont switch back to the main screen.. it will just turn on for 5 seconds and then go black. The only way to make it work is to restart my computer with the dock still connected.  So basically, anytime my computer sleeps or is locked.. it will bug out like that. good video
Approximately two years ago, I began observing overvolting issues on my ROG Crosshair VIII Hero, coupled with the Ryzen 9 5950X processor. When default BIOS settings were applied, the CPU core voltage was automatically set to 1.48V. This configuration intermittently pushed the processor to achieve an overclocking speed of 5.2GHz, albeit momentarily, before reverting to its base frequency. This sporadic overclocking resulted in significant thermal issues due to overheating.  To address this problem, I customized a profile to constrain the CPU boost frequency at 3.4GHz and set the core voltage to a maximum of 1.35V. These modifications effectively mitigated the overheating issues by maintaining a consistent and lower operational frequency, along with an appropriately reduced core voltage.  Moreover, I own a 32GB Corsair Vengeance DDR4 3600MHz memory kit (composed of four 8GB modules). I've been confronted with an issue where, if I try to overclock the memory to 3800MHz, the BIOS does not proceed with the boot sequence. This issue persists despite contacting Corsair, who kindly provided a full replacement warranty for all four modules.  The recurrence of the problem, even after the RAM replacement, suggests that the issue may not lie with the memory modules themselves, but potentially with the Asus motherboard.

I usually stick with Gigabyte (and occasionally MSI) as a personal preference but I bought an ASUS board (ASUS x570-e Gaming) last year for my latest personal build because of the RGB design. I just wanted something a bit more flashy for myself. I suffered through the pains of it for several months. TPM kept causing issues and failing causing Windows 11 to be unhappy, and I kept getting blue screens from a dozen different errors causing me to think my RAM and a rather expensive GPU were failing but it was weird because I would never get the same exact error twice, not even in the logs or in tests. Long story short (there were more issues including a daily fight with Armory Crate), the ASUS board was a disaster and I went back to Gigabyte. Not a single issue since. Fun fact: just because a manufacturer SAYS doing x will void your warranty doesnt automatically make it so! Thats been established law for decades, but the public doesnt know. "Warranty void if this sticker is removed" is an absolute lie!   You have to do something that directly leads to the fault to legally void your warranty! Ex: if you replace a fan and the audio developes a problem, the burden of proof is on the manufacturer to prove you replacing the fan directly caused the audio syatem to have a problem.if they cant, then legally they need to fix the audio problem in warranty.
Solid as an "Asrock".  hahahaha....glad i made it this far; the levity reminded me why i watch this channel. Seemingly this has become their business model.  F'em.  Keep up the good fight!

I gotta say, Jay, that I stand with you. I have had software problems with my TG H670 Pro wifi D4. I ran the fan auto-tuner in Asus Armoury Crate (AAC) because I wanted to get the best curves. It nerfed my Noctua iPPC-3000 down to a stupidly low level, resulting in my system being hotter (during winter with my thermostat at 60 F). Then, when I tried to manually alter the curves using AAC, the tuner would NOT allow them to be changed, and would not allow BIOS to over-ride it, either.  Then, I uninstalled AAC BUT THE APP CONTROLLING THE FANS WAS NOT UNINSTALLED. I had to use Task Manager to stop it, then I had to go into the startup folder to disable it, restarted and my fans were back under MY control.  TBF, on the LTT forums, I've recently seen some similar complaints with other brands' software dominating fans and AIOs.  The customer service experience that I had with them ranged from good to horrible, but mostly closer to horrible. If you use live-chat, the agents are forced to handle several customers at a time and the one I dealt with wasn't taking notes and wasn't paying attention to the chat history, so I finally gave up. The phone agents try to get you off the line as quickly as possible so that they can email you with instructions. Basically, almost every request for help or information has resulted in them sending a form that doesn't show why they're contacting me ANYWHERE, and asks me to fill out a form and send it back, even though I had ALREADY verbally or in chat told them the problem in great detail. Worse yet, if I DID actually bother to fill out the form, and I happened to have multiple trouble tickets, they'd reuse the ticket number and NOT specify which problem they were responding to, WHILE ALSO RESPONDING TO CLOSED PROBLEMS. One problem, which involved the above chat/phone/form fiasco, was in regards to why I couldn't get the H670 to recognize my SSD, which prevented me from installing Windows. It turned that, because I had Intel Rapid Storage Technology turned on, it was removed from consideration for OS installation and could ONLY be used for RAID. I tried multiple things to try to fix it, contacted the SSD manufacturer (TeamGroup, who also failed miserably to provide adequate support before passing me to Asus), and then dealt with this nonsense. THE AGENT SENT ME BAD, INCOMPLETE AND CONFUSING TROUBLESHOOTING INSTRUCTIONS, some of the steps were things I'd already told him I'd tried, and others were stupid or incomprehensible, and never identified the problem. I figured it out the SAME DAY, told them I'd resolved the issue and expressed my displeasure with their poor service (video and email). They kept emailing me about it and other things that had been resolved, although I wasn't always sure what they were writing about because they didn't indicate which topic while lumping them together on one trouble ticket despite being opened separately.  And, hey, best of all I continued to get emails about the SSD issue for the next 2 months.  In my opinion, Asus is as you say - arrogant and they've sunk pretty low. Thank you for sharing your experience with everyone!
