May 14, 2023 - The HDMI out on my ASUS ROG STRIX Z790-A Gaming WiFi motherboard stopped working after having the board for about five months. I only bought the ASUS board because I was waiting to see if EVGA would honor the RMA on my returned Z690 motherboard. The ASUS board was available on Amazon for a reasonable price, and i thought I would "upgrade" while waiting to see if EVGA would send me a replacement Z690 motherboard. The ASUS motherboard has worked for about five months, but the "HDMI out" on the board TOTALLY stopped working for both my PC monitor and my TV, when I downloaded a Microsoft Windows 11 "upgrade". I thought there could be a driver problem and downloaded ASUS drivers for the motherboard hoping that would correct the problem. I didn't download ASUS Bios drivers because I was concerned about the necessity of "renaming" Bios files. One issue I notice when building my PC, was that the ASUS board required that I install a support rack for the EVGA RTX3080 Ti GPU. I didn't have to install a support rack for the GPU when I installed it on my EVGA Z299 Dark motherboard. Two years ago, I purchased the Asus ROG Maximus XIII Hero motherboard, and it worked perfectly until I decided to replace it with the Asus ROG Maximus Z690 Formula. Unfortunately, while removing the old motherboard, I accidentally bent some pins. I reached out to Asus Support for assistance and requested a CPU socket replacement. I sent the motherboard to them, but they informed me that since the damage was caused by the customer (me), I would have to pay for the socket replacement. Reluctantly, I made the payment, and after a few days, they contacted me to inform me that despite changing the socket, the motherboard was no longer functioning. They mentioned that it had failed during the final examination and shipped it back to me.  I was frustrated because I had explained to them that I hadn't done anything else to the motherboard besides the minor accident. Prior to removing it from my case, it was working perfectly fine. Their response was for me to try it out and see if it would work, and if not, I could discard it.  Since then, I have kept the motherboard aside as I no longer have a suitable processor to test it with. It's possible that it may still be functioning, but I cannot be certain.  I do have a positive opinion of Asus overall, as I currently have the Z790 Hero working flawlessly with my 13900K and Nvidia 4090. However, their customer support leaves much to be desired, and they definitely need to improve their post-purchase services. Otherwise, they risk losing more customers in the future and becoming obsolete.

It is small issues suggesting underlying bigger problem... from the way company name products (WTF is RoG class?), their pricing (motherboards as expensive as prior-to-last-generation high-end graphics card?) and their quality. What these companies do not understand is that they do not protect they brand by hiding issues and pushing more ads. Those "brands" are earned by years of quality products, reasonable pricing, variety of products with different combination of features for different customer types, communications with customers and B2B with their partners (like AMD), etc. What they are currently doing is trading hard-earned reputation for money. Once they run out of reputation, they will run out of money as well.
I personally love Asus so this really sucks, but accountability is something allot of companies have lost site of. Hopefully this kicks their ass in gear. Appreciate what you do J. Much love to you and the crew.

I too fired ASUS some years back. I had an ASUS GTX570 that failed in an interesting way.  During gaming it would crash sporadically, so I purchased the Heaven benchmark so that I could put a load on the graphics card without having to sit there and play a game. It could run for 24hr on DX9 but if you switched to DX11 (or was it 12) it would crash typically inside an hour of use. I was able to repeat this by pulling the card out and putting it in a completely different PC and the same thing would happen so I was confident it was the card. I took it back to the retailer once and ASUS themselves twice. ASUS simply took the card and the next thing I'd know is it was shipped back to me. No-one would communicate with me so I could describe the problem so they could test for it themselves. It simply came back as supposedly working. I'd test it the same way and get the same result. In the end I sold the card on the 2nd hand market clearly stipulating the issue the card had and as such I got only $20 for it which was fair enough really. Time is money and the amount of time I put into testing that card and the fact that I also bought testing software to in the end get nothing was very frustrating so at that time I swore off ever buying an ASUS product again, not because of the fault, but I didn't want to ever have to deal with the terrible customer service again. I also swore off that retailer too, again I didn't want to have to deal with their customer service again either. I was inclined to think my experience was perhaps limited to my own country or the staff at the time, but this piece shows the badness goes to the top and makes me glad I've stayed away from ASUS. I recently had to RMA an Intel i9-10900K and whilst it was a drawn out process it did get resolved and I have a replacement CPU.

Working at a tech retailer, Asus has consistently been the very worst brand for warranty and repairs. They will send back a board with a fault confirmed by our techs as obvious as "no power on" with "BIOS updated, no fault found", and when we test it again it's still doing the same thing. We do not have this issue with MSI, Gigabyte, or Asrock, who will repair or replace with a new/refurb product. Asus has a QVL for literally every part in a computer and if your test bench didn't only consist of those approved parts they sometimes won't even listen to you (note that most of their own products are not featured on these QVLs). Asus has an extremely strong brand image and we constantly get customers insisting on an Asus product because they want the best and don't want an alternative from an "inferior" brand, despite our experience telling us that Asus is at the bottom of the tier list in many ways. With how much they charge for some of their premium products I expect much better service and warranty than they actually provide.

Repairing ASUS laptops I saw a steady decline in quality. This particularly concerns the product's design and it seems to have affected their budget products long before it began affecting the more top-end ones. Like $1200 laptops with wobbly shells around the mousepad, which exerted pressure on sensitive components from simply the weight of the average user's hand. This is when I started seeing warped connectors leading to a separate PCB containing the SATA reader chip, headphone jack and additional USB ports, resulting in simultaneous intermittent failures to read either the bootable drive, the sound card or the additional USB. Right there and then it became obvious that replacing the PCB or the motherboard altogether would simply lead to exactly the same issue re-occurring with new components because of the crappy design of the plastic/aluminum shells and support post placement. I had to advice the owners of laptops that weren't even 2 years old to just buy a new laptop from a different manufacturer like MSI. It is rather unfortunate because there was a time when I could swear by ASUS quality.
When they reach the top, but then forget how they got there.

I just hope you don't expect a better user experience with either MSO or ASROCK with RMAs...  You want the RMA experience MSI one in a nutshell, take your faulty product, box it up by the standards set forth, pay for and print the shipping label, and just throw it in the trash, because that's about all the good I have ever seen their warranty coverage amount to, they have a tendency of getting "lost in the mail" after delivery to the warranty center, as they will insist they never received it even when the tracking says they did.  And ASRock's isn't much better.  They might receive it, but they are still going to charge you for the warranty repairs.  And it still may not work.  And all this over an issue with a specific Chipset and CPU combo, that happens with other brands as well?  And an RMA issue of getting the wrong board?  I mean, at least you got a replacement.  And it's particularly the X670E and the "7800X6D" /s.  And it happens differently on ASUS than on other brands.  They are working on a fix and haven't finalized it yet.  And you say you are for the customer, but you have made a number of statements lately that cause me to question that.  "Water Cooling for everyone!" would be a for the consumer statement, but your recent statement in another video of "You should have put that money towards a better graphics card [if you want water cooling]" is very much not a for the consumer statement, as but one example.  Show us you are for the consumer, and help us the option of water cooling to tame our 20/3060's and RX 5500XT's with runaway hotspots that hit thermal shutdown before the before the ambient die temp has the fan curve at maximum fan speed in a market where it cost more for a mid range or low end GPUs than it did top tier just a few years short ago...  $500 used to be the top tier GPUs not all that long ago, now you're lucky to get a low end or mid range GPU for that much, and they are all made with a ticking fuse of a cooling solution no matter how over spec'd the cooler itself is.  A thermal solution is only as good as it's slowest transfer rates, and those stock thermal pads are really slow to transfer heat.  And with minimal contact at that, which acts more as an insulator than a conductor of heat at the low rate of thousandths of watts per difference in face temperatures at 6 W/mK vs tenths of watts of metal on metal for IHS or metal on die (235-398 W/mK) with thermal paste applied over a volume of cubic millimeters.  And it doesn't help that windows update drivers take precedence over manufacturer drivers and take away our control of factors that affect the life of the hardware that aren't available with a windows update driver installed.  Even the mid range GPU in many people's systems cost more than the rest of the system put together these days.

Software of Gigabyte is crap as well, but at least not breaking anything.  Missing the days of more choice in consumer motherboard brands. Gone are the days of DFI, Epox, ECS Elitegroup and others which had all their one product to shine in a generation.  Nowadays for AMD there are only 5 brands in Europe: ASUS, ASRock, Gigabyte, MSI and Biostar. Finally on a last note jay I have watched both of your CPU and Motherboard videos, and well I completely agree with just about everything you have to say and I only see one small issue your not covering in your video's I would really liked stressed to manufacturer's....Well the problem is that all the motherboards seem to have 3 PCIE lanes and 3 M.2 slots but in reality the CPU does NOT support all 3 of both being used, in reality You only ever need 1 PCIE x16 and 1 NVME m.2 slot, if there are 10+ sata ssd slots that would be fine because the cpu does not use 4 lanes for sata....why am I still seeing boards with 3x PCIE x16 and 3X M.2 slots when you can only use 1 of each slot EVER!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!......The only solution to this madness is to manufacture cpu's with more then 20 pcie lanes or just stop manufacturing boards this way and only manufacture boards with 1 x PCIE x16 lanes and 1 x M.2 slots reserving the space on motherboards for more important STUFF!!!!! Or you could start doing like old 775 board I have and give us a 32 lane chip to support more lanes for PCIE accessories! Also Jay i want to make a point about high price motherboards vs low price motherboards, If you buy a graphics card you do not need any special VRAM on your motherboard, remember you can only use 1 driver, so if your buying a 4090 card you do not need a motherboard with good VRAM becuase your graphics card has it...but...if your wanting to game without a graphics card you will need to go with Z or X series chipsets becuase the VRAM is meant for 4k gaming without a graphics card!!! ITS THE ONLY REASON MOTHERBOARD PRICES ARE THIS WAY JAY BUT I AGREE WITH YOU ITS WRONG!!!!

It's how a company responds to those issues that makes or breaks the end user confidence, in that brand. For example, the plastic around hinges on my MSI Raider laptop cracked... MSI offered to replace the laptop (for free), if I sent it back to them... I wasn't in a location that would allow me to send them my laptop... SO I took it upon myself to order the replacement parts and fix the laptop myself... MSI's reply was basically "we are sorry that we can't give you those parts for free, but if you ever want to return the laptop to us we will still replace it, even after you have fixed it yourself"... I will continue to to buy MSI products. Not because they are they best... BUT when I wanted to do something a certain way, they were still willing to stand behind their product and still honor their original offer. That kind of response goes a long way towards confidence in a brand.

I returned 2 RAM kits thinking it couldn't have been my ASUS board, but sure enough it was a subpar memory controller.   This generation with an x670e TUF board and a 7900x my computer with normal CPU and EXPO settings would suddenly cut power as if there were a surge or spark.  I ruled out the PSU by swapping it, and ruled out a short circuit by rebuilding the whole thing.  I found that the only way I can keep it stable is with the CPU set to eco mode and Expo turned off.  Sucks major balls but at least I know the reason now.  Partially my fault for trusting ASUS and believing my last gen board was just a lemon.
I stopped buying ASUS, which was my favorite brand, several years ago. Had problems with memory on a ASUS board and wrote them. Detailing everything I had tried. I got a "Have you tried rebooting" reply after 3 weeks. From then on I haven't used them. Mostly opting for MSI, their customer support is quick to reply, haven't had RMA need on any of their products yet. Next AM5 build will be MSI as well I think

Since forever Asus has had bad support, they just used to be worth it in the past because they had enough quality advantage over most competitors that most buyers didn't have to deal with support.  Now that the quality advantage  is eroded and anti-consumer practices are common across all PC component manufacturers it's clear Asus has lost the only advantage they ever had.
As much as I hate to say it, spot on and good move. The issue of Asus' cack-handed UEFI development - and abject changelog/documentation, has been festering for months. I've been dealing with a Z690 Hero that was turned from a stable platform to an unreliable mess by a beta BIOS update last December - that contained an entirely undocumented feature - the inability to remove it or flash back to a previous stable build. The only practical way to get the system back to reasonable stability was to significantly chop memory bus speeds - with the ensuing performance hit.  When I eventually got some response from Asus, the cure was long in coming, and still not as good as where it was, although users have also now discovered how to circumvent the flash block and go back to earlier builds.  In the meantime, many other users have been dealing with similar issues and been caught by the undocumented regression block - which Asus have started noting in their changelogs only *very* recently, and for very spurious reasons (supposedly compliance with Japanese wifi standards).   Language barriers are one thng. Downright shoddy behaviour and poor treatment of customers who are paying top dollar for supposedly premium products is another.  On the upside, my Hero didn't have the reverse cap. On the other, it's had a flaky and unreliable onboard NIC (another common problem) since purchase.   Next time, I'll be looking elsewhere. Probably toward EVGA, given they're one of the few tech companies that's enhanced their rep for doing the right thing over the last couple of years. If only I could still buy their graphics cards.

To add on to this, when I first got the original board, I noticed something weird was happening with the voltage/wattage.  Whenever I tried to run Cinebench, the application would instantly crash(like zero seconds) and sometimes the computer would blue screen.  This was without messing with the settings.  From what I could tell, the temperatures were instantly spiking to 100 degrees and crashing.  There was absolutely no thermal throttling.  After looking in the bios, it appeared that ASUS had pretty much removed the wattage limit.  Rather then Intel's stock of 253W turbo, I believe it was well over 800W.  I have no idea what they were thinking doing this, and I am lucky that my chip didn't burn out.  Fortunately, they released a BIOS update, but even that appears to just be a lazy workaround that limits the CPU to 90 degrees when you could probably get a little more performance by running it slightly hotter.  And then of course there is the malware/bloatware that is Armory Crate that I refused to install the second time after being forced to reinstall Windows 11 due to a plethora of bugs.  I bought this board because I thought that ASUS was THE company that I could trust to buy a good motherboard from.  Yikes, was I wrong....

To everyone out there, spread the word, don't let companies like Asus get away with it: Contact whatever consumer protection authority acts in your country if your stuff breaks when you use it within spec, if you have trouble getting it replaced. That's a faulty product and in many countries either the shop that sold it, or the manufacturer is responsible regardless of *any* warranty statements they make.   ASUS Armoury Crate = worst software solution I've ever tried, after decades of daily PC use as both a profession and a hobby. It's like malware that attaches itself into everything your operating system has, service by service, background process by background process, its tendrils latch on and won't let go. It says something that due to how unstable and "dirty" the software is, they have a separate "uninstall tool" that TRIES to clean up your system from leftover Armoury Crate files, settings and processes when something inevitably goes wrong with it and you just try to do a normal uninstall which fails. But it never* succeeds in doing a cleanup, and advice you will eventually get from support after the usual back and forth is "reinstall your OS". No kidding. I've cleaned malware infections, including some quite tricky ones from multiple PCs over the years, and with full honesty I can say it was much more work and more time consuming to find out what was wrong with a Windows PC after Armoury Crate did a number on it than any malware I remember dealing with. That was in no small part due to it taking 30 minutes to install it on a fairly modern PC (Fast Internet, SSD) just to see if the problem of it neither running, or uninstalling properly still exists. I was *this* close to asking the person I was helping if we could reinstall the OS, but luckily (I will say it was mostly luck) I managed to fix things, and just have Aura installed for LED control, since it's small(er) and not causing issues on that particular system.  Okay but that's just one (albeit pretty important for the features you paid for) piece of software right? If only. They can't even get something as simple as onboard sound card's control software right, when it's one of the big "gaming" features the board was advertised with. From settings being randomly lost on reboot to mixing stereo sound (music) into multiple speakers resulting in unusable sound quality, it's a hit and miss. Yet from the software you can see someone did make a real effort. There's a lot of features, and a most of it works fine, at least according to my limited experience. The most frustrating part as someone trying to fix an issue is their attitude that is "Since only X number of people are complaining about this on the forums, we will randomly link standard trouble shooting steps, and ignore it (for years)". While other users with the issue who clearly know their stuff just say "Don't bother, just buy an old sound card for $20 on Ebay, it will do a better job". Spoiler: It does.  I've dealt with some annoying motherboard related hardware issues too (X570), but as I can't confirm if they were "Asus only", or how they were dealt with by the powers that be, I won't rant about them here.

For those who don't know Those "influencer stacks" are actually B-stock  companies have. B stock is normally returns, Refurbished, RMAs, and sometimes old revisions  Companies send these out when they need to give someone a "free" or loaner hardware  There's nothing wrong with B stock, it's just when you pass it off as perfect is the problem

You see, there are several things you need to know about warranties in the US ASUS. I learned much of this from lawyers who cover car warranties but the same rules apply to everything with a warranty. The first critial thing you have to remember when writing a warranty is that anything expressed in the advertisements to sell the product, cannot be disclaimed/undone with a disclaimer. These advertizements are called "expressed warranty". These are things like, the engine displacement or HP on the advertisement, website, or window sticker for a car. Another example would be a newspaper advertisement for a TV at a department store that said the screen size, resolution, and refresh rate. This even applies to used cars. Now the other kind of warranty is called an "implied warranty" lets talk about cars again as an example. An implied warranty is that the car runs and is in good condition,  another implied warranty is that the car is legal to drive and licence in the state it is being sold(and the county as a whole) With an implied warranty, you can disclaim your obligations in almost all instaces with a warranty disclaimer like "sold as is" Again critically "sold as is" does not cover expressed warranties In other words, if a used car lot advertizes a COPO camaro that "dyno tested to 900HP, engine just inspected and will last thousands of miles" they can still sell it as is, but if it doesnt dyno test to at or around 900HP(or over), or if it breaks down after 1500 miles of normal driving, then they still have to cover their expressed warranty.  Now lets talk about something in the electronics industry For instance, lets take this totally hypothetical scenario, if the product page for say, a SUSA GOR Gunsight X670E Intensity says "supports 6400MT/s RAM" Then a warranty from say, a BIOS update from SUSA cannot legally disclaim that, not even the warranty for the X670E motherboard can disclaim it.  Another critical thing is that, if you make 3rd party parts, and your part damages a different company's part, you might be on the hook for damages, even if your part was undamaged, though with electronics this complex, damage is very hard to point definite blame, even with damage this obvious, most damage of this nature is invisible, exploding CPUs basically never happen.
Truly. SCREW YOU ASUS ðŸ–•ðŸ–•ðŸ–•ðŸ–• . Try to pull such a dirty handed tactic to rid yourselves of having to honor warranty claims, you don't deserve to have any customers.

As a former ASUS employee, none of this surprises me. After laying me off, they tried to push me into signing a form that said I would never say anything negative about ASUS, its current/future products, or current/future employees. If I do ever say anything negative, they assured me they would take legal action. Since I didn't sign it, I received no severance pay (they offered a paltry 3 weeks' pay if I signed), which goes against the whole "we're a family" thing that they push on you from the moment you join.  Edit: For those asking, the document was called a "Non-disparagement agreement" and while it wasn't illegal at the time, such practices have been outlawed in the US since. I would guess that they don't use this practice any longer, but they did when I was laid off last year.

The issues you described with the usb & audio problems likely indicate a motherboard issue rathaer than a CPU issue. Could be chipset, could be electrical fault around the peripheral ports.  The CPU does not interact with audio and usb directly, and were it a software driver issue it would likely repeat across multiple cpu models.

One thing about Asus: They used to overclock their Boards for a long time, only slightly to gain 2-5% in Tests. The Bios and their Software shows good parameters but good Software and direkt measurements show that Asus always go for the upper range of the tolerance on DEFAULT Setting. So the 1.41V instead of 1.35 comes at no suprise for me, it's literally the allowed 0.5% tolerance, Problems comes when you go at the upper limit and still have a 0.1% tolerance when a Sensor heats up, then you get a Crash. Same goes for Audiocards, they expect normal Bus Timings. They expect a PCIE Base Clock of 100mhz +- 1.5%. Asus delievers on default a Baseclock of 101.5 mhz. It improves greatly the GPU Performance, winning the Performance Crown for the ASUS Boards. But a Soundchip or USB Chip connected to this 101.5 Mhz Chip is in danger of getting Hotspots and have those Problems Jay has experienced. Other Brands do the other way around, like Asrock, they are a subsidary from the same Mother Company, but they clock at 99.5mhz. So Asus Boards are Faster and they are slower. But guess what, they are more stable. Same goes for Gigabyte, the tend to underclock ther Bus Speeds as well. Since i swapped from Asus to Gigabyte, i never had an Peripherial Error again. P5Q-Pro was my last Asus Board. I work as a Systemadministrator at Schools and have time and again Problems with Asus Boards, with components dying. Another Cheap component which don't like to be overclocked are Realtek NIC Chips. Guess how funny it is, when you have one after another Asus Board ( 2017 Models) having dying NIC when they are out of warrenty and you have a total loss, or have to buy pcie NIC Cards to keep the maschine working.
I had no Problems with asrock since 2016

I still have time to return my motherboard and get a different brand that's hopefully better and doesn't release firmware updates that void your warranty.  I don't know of a better way to try to change this practice than sending it back to the vendor.

I watched this video hoping that there was new information, that perhaps the issue wasn't as bad as I feared. I always used to have the impression that ASUS was more or less a gold standard when it came to motherboards years ago. However, the last several boards I have gotten have all had various issues. Even boards I ended up exchanging or RMA'ing, their replacements would still have USB controller issues, stability issues, etc. In particular, the B350 and x470 ASUS boards in my personal experience and admittedly small sample size have been nothing but problems.   I am willing to put up with a certain level of QC issues (which seemingly have gotten worse in recent years with ASUS), but as Jay mentioned... it comes down to how the manufacturer handles issues and takes care of their customers. If they would have just come clean and put out a notice that a big problem existed with these x670 boards, and laid out a plan to fix the problem and make sure the customer is taken care of.... this would be a much, much, much smaller deal.   This really seals the deal for me. I think I'm finally making the permanent switch to exclusively EVGA mobos, even if that means switching back to intel. EVGA seems to be the only manufacturer with integrity left.

I build my first AMD system (since 18+ years) in early 2021 that used Asus MB. Since the beginning I had weird issues with my PC failling to shutdown (fans go to 100%, code 04 "Detect HDD" on the MB screen), system starting on it's own with all boot over X and wakes disabled in BIOS, or simply freezing in Windows and showing random error codes on the MB screen. I ended up replacing both Motherboard and PSU. Some issues went away but some are still there. It's a very long story of me trying different stuff for a year. The replacement process with Asus was bad. My mint condition board was replaced with one that had bottom right corner bent and broken front power LED (0V on between the pins). Plastic cover for chipset fan was not glued properly and it was sticking. And had scuffs all over the board and cooling pieces. It took me weeks going back and forth of sharing shipping box photos and explanations to finally get another replacement (btw. the box was too small and someone forced the MB into it, otherwise the box had no damages). They replaced the board but they reused cooling and plates from the previous one. So I still had the unglued chipset fan cover and scuffed plastics and cooling. But at least front power LED was working...
My father swore off ASUS over a decade ago because of a string of bad experiences. I had gotten the impression from more recent YouTube coverage that they had improved. Guess not.

I do think that there were a lot of compounding issues from both AMD and Intel this generation, which is causing more instability this generation than ever before. DDR5 being new, power limits and turbo limits being higher than ever, more and faster pci devices than before with gen 4 ssds and graphics cards being the norm for anyone building with this generation.  Not to mention the design for all of these parts likely happened during the pandemic and potentially work from home.  It's not an excuse for bad quality conrtrol, but the fanciest most expensive boards needed to come out when the cpus came out because the kinds of people that buy the most expensive boards and cpus are mostly trying to get them when they are brand new. I am not really defending Asus, but I can see why things are going wrong, and I wouldn't even expect the problems people have been having with Asus to be limited just to them.  edit- If someone knows a PC part company with good support let me know.

@JayzTwoCents Sad to see this happen to ASUS, I've used their motherboards since 1996.  For your sound dropping issue, it has to do with the USB I/O controller. I had the same problem with an X3D processor and the culprit was having USB 2.0 audio, not 3.0 - for whatever reason, Gen4 PCI-EXPRESS requires all the USBs connected to be 3.0 or it'll crackle and drop out.  Fiber/SPDIF/Out gets around this issue but it's just a bit of shortsightedness and growing pains with AM4/AM5.  See if you have the same trouble with an MSI board and USB 2.0+Gen4 to double check :)
Absolutely disappointing because out of all the brands I wouldâ€™ve loved to be pure ASUS

Honestly this is really disheartening. I though that I would go to ASUS for my next GPU now that EVGA is out of the game. I don't trust MSI that much. they're the only company I've had any real issues or failures with in the past with GPU and at least one motherboard. I DO NOT trust Gigabyte at all, their customer support is possibly the worst on the planet out of everyone.  That being said I do love ASRock. I've bought 4 or 5 motherboards from them and they've all been flawless. What made me go back to them was my experience in 2016 when I rebuilt my main rig with an X99 Extreme4. I bought the board and the CPU separately and as some of us know there were a few generations with the the 2011 socket. I went out and bough an i7-6800K assuming that it was compatible, and NOPE! So I talked to ASRock support to see if there was anything that could be done, and I was willing to pay for things if necessary. I just didn't want to have to try and find and older CPU that matched up with the BIOS. Well, at the end of the call their service person said that the BIOS chip is replaceable on that particular board and that they'd be willing to send another one. I said that would be wonderful and that I'd be more than willing to wait for it. She told me that'd be perfect and that since she already has my info on file that they'd send one within a few business days at no cost to me. I was floored. Low and behold less than a week went by, the chip showed up, I threw it in, and everything fired right up. Since then every board that I've gotten from ASRock as been....rock solid.....and I'd be hard pressed to find a reason at this point to go with someone other than them (except for maybe EVGA).

I took pictures and tried a warranty claim, they responded that this is not covered under warranty due do abuse of the product. I gave up the warranty claim after a week of back and forth emailing, due to not having any proof of treating the laptop correctly. This was until more and more people at my university started to have the same issue. The laptop was sold through the university, so many students had the same model. Asus kept refusing any warranty, even after emailing them pictures of 10 identical laptops, with 10 identical crumbling monitor bezels. The laptop experienced also some overheating issues, so I tried applying new cooling paste to the CPU. Three of the four CPU heat-sink screws broke of when unscrewing them, due to being of garbage quality. Was able to fix it by drilling out the left over part of the screws, got it to work another year or so. The laptop barely made it 2.5 years and was a huge waste of money. Never have I had such garbage computer in my life!  I then had an Asus GTX1060 GPU, which failed three times within it's two years warranty period. I'm lucky to live in Europe, where each repair get's in itself a new two year warranty period. This has been going on for 6 years now.   Also had an Asus Zenbook, where the soldered on caching SSD failed after 1.2 years. They refused warranty on it, due to having to many writes to the SSD. Asus being the one that chose this type of soldered on SSD as cache disk in the first place. The bios refused to continue it's boot procedure, with the defective (soldered) SSD connected to it. This bricked the full laptop, even after installing another 3.5 inch sata ssd to it. I got it to work, after de-soldering the VCC and GND pins of the SSD IC, disconnecting them from the motherboard. This laptop still works till this day, but only thanks to my embedded electronics background.  I've been avoiding asus as the plague!  I'm happy to see that others are also getting updated on their scummy behavior.
So who do you buy if not ASUS, don don duhhhh

I appreciate you and others calling ASUS out on this. AMD seems to have a history of partner issues when new platforms are rolled out. I remember the VIA chipset days around the turn of the century (yeah, I'm old) and needing to replace my PC. Being an AMD fanboy (and previous employee) I attempted to gather the parts, but I couldn't find a stable combination. I think some of these challenges is what led to AMD to start producing their own chipsets around that same time, although VIA was still mainstream for the home/budget PC builder. Thankfully things eventually stabilized, but I went Intel for years due to the quality of available platforms to use from AMD partners -- so AMD needs to step up here as well, as this affects their reputation even if not directly at fault. I guarantee that there are people scrambling at ASUS to address this, they just have processes and procedures they are following that don't account for an issue like this. But, now is a good time to address this and be open about it with their customers.

10:00 Random Blue screen and a few other quirky things. Do you regularly check the Windows install. I have windows 11 on my previous gen build Desktop I put together a few months ago and Windows 10 pro on a Laptop. Each one is having the same issue. I run Chkdsk and after a few weeks errors appear but running Chkdsk /scan fixes that. Then run SFC /Scannow that's where the main issue is both the desktop and laptop this error keeps cropping up: "Windows Resource Protection found corrupt files but was unable to fix some of them. Details are included in the CBS.Log windir\Logs\CBS\CBS.log. For example C:\Windows\Logs\CBS\CBS.log."   To fix that issue You need to go to C:Windows\Logs\DISM\dism.log and delete that file (seems this file gets corrupted and might be the culprit. Microsoft is aware of this issue going on years now and haven't fixed it). Then run via again command prompt with admin: DISM /Online /Cleanup-image /StartComponentCleanup and then DISM /Online /Cleanup-image /RestoreHealth. This cleans everything up and the random Windows blue screen stops,  sluggishness and programs dropping until the errors start cropping up again.  Now this is on two separate devices from two different time periods. The desktop with the previous gen hardware and the laptop a bit older.  Other than that, both devices run fine. I know that Windows 11 is exactly the same kernel as Windows 10 but with a different gui and other tweaks. I found all those fixes due to the issues and finding errors.   BTW the desktop is: MSI MAG X570S Tomahawk WiFi Motherboard, AMD Ryzen 9 5900X 12-core, Corsair Vengeance LPX 32GB DDR4 3200, Samsung 970 EVO Plus SSD 1TB NVMe M.2 and MSI Gaming AMD Radeon RX 6600 128-bit 8GB GDDR6. The Laptop is an HP Silver Envy.

just AMD things tbh. I'm on an MSI X570 Tomahawk with a 5900X and basically from the beginning I had weird bluescreens and memory errors.  As it turns out it was caused by the RAM which was running at the advertised speeds and which is also supported (both the model of the RAM as well as the frequency) according to the manual. I had to manually underclock it to the next lower frequency and ever since then I haven't had a single bluescreen.

The sonic suite is just one example -- I know it can be uninstalled now; for years it was unremovable from your machine unless you swapped the motherboard. Sonic suite wasn't harmful in and of itself, but it sets a very risky precedent as informed hackers always have a backdoor if they learn to crack one of the preinstalled programs. And if the user can never get it off the system... Just doesn't make a lot of sense from a security perspective.

I have an Asus Prime X670E-Pro Wifi w/7950X (non-3d) and had my own weird issue.   After tons of weird issues (Steam games hanging before starting, Java applications, including Minecraft, with severe video issues--even causing an instantaneous shutdown of the system), I finally found a solution:   I had to force onboard video OFF.   Auto was not sufficient.   Problems went away instantly.   I have a brand new PG48UQ that had issues with the screen blacking out that I sent back for repair, but they never recreated the issue.   The above onboard GPU disable seems to have even fixed that somehow (no other monitors were ever affected the same way).

I ordered a Z790 Extreme for my new build, right on release in october 2022. I received the board in november and finished the build in mid december 2022 (cause of delivery problems on some parts). And well, what can I say. The board was running 2 or 3 weeks, then it broke down. It grilled the DIMM.2 Slot (at least not my M.2 or the 13900KF...) and two of my four Dominator Sticks. I RMA'd the board in february 2023. It was sent to ASUS and all they could say that it was broken. There was no spare for it, bc the board was already on EOL status, 5 months after release! after finding out about this Asus bs I thought it would be a good idea to check out my auto settings so I went into my bios (z370 tuf gaming ii with 9600k and 32gb of 3600mhz ram) and discovered that auto was feeding my cpu VCCIO Voltage 1.4v it now is set to and stable at 1.15v and my System Agent Voltage was at 1.42 it is now set to and stable at 1.20v both of those auto settings are very high it makes me wonder if they have been bumping up the auto voltages on the boards going back longer than this fiasco

"stuff"
I posted this on HU's channel but I'll repeat it here:  I contacted ASUS and noticed the disclaimer in their quick fix bios that basically said if I use it and something breaks it's my own fault. I questioned this and asked them specifically which BIOS I should use, they told me in writing not to use the beta BIOS. I used thier AI software to set an SOC voltage limit of 1.3v myself.  With the SOC voltage limit manually set I turned on Expo1 again. Interesting observation, the cpu ran to 5050 MHz when I originally set Expo1 to on (before the problems surfaced) but with the limit applied it runs to 4800 instead. This suggests the voltage may have been exceeding 1.3v previously on my system. I'm also running 5600 MHz RAM, which was an intentional purchase choice, and the lower speed made help but I couldn't say that with any authority.

I understand that the issue needs immediate attention, but I've been working in tech for a long time, and have seen a lot of beta firmware versions for things that generally come with a disclaimer saying "This could damage your device, and it will not be covered under warranty if you use it".  They make the beta versions so people can test them, not so the masses can use them as something that's "In production".  If you're willing to be in the test group, then generally you understand the risks.  I don't blame Jay for cutting ties with ASUS, but being mad about them putting a disclaimer on their BIOS feels like average redditor energy.

I am torn on this one. I 100% agree that they shouldn't have released a beta bios at all... just release a recommendation on turning off EXPO and soc voltages.  On the other hand, I think they are panicking because they know this is a serious issue and are trying to do something asap to address it... which in this is case a bios that they must have some level of confidence in otherwise I don't think they would even consider releasing it.  With the intent of hopefully heading off this catastrophic failure issue.  But at the same time, I can see the side of this is only a test version and can put your warranty in jeopardy.   The logical thing to do here is disable EXPO and lower the SoC voltage to 1.3v... and wait until they release a final version in the near future.  It isn't rocket science.

I once traveled across the country via train, and took my PC along with me in checked baggage. When I arrived at my destination and tried to set up the computer, it would not boot. I checked all the obvious stuff (with one foolish exception) and finally called Gigabyte (the MB manufacturer). They walked me through a few more things to check, but it still would not boot at all. There was none of this _'find some excuse not to help the customer'_ crap. They shipped me the same MB I already had, at their expense.  When I went to start pulling things off the (assumed) dead MB, I noticed that the locking-lever on the CPU wasn't latched-down (how embarrassing!). I locked it down, and the system booted up flawlessly. Feeling like a complete ass, I called Gigabyte back, told them what I'd found and asked if they wanted me to ship the unopened new MB back to them. They were like, _"Nah, keep it as a backup. Glad you were able to get your system running again!"_ I've stuck with Gigabyte ever since. What absolute heroes! ðŸ‘

Jay, I'll add my own recent experience with Asus products.  A couple of Months ago I ordered an ROG Strix X670E-E Gaming WiFi board and a Ryzen 7950x CPU to go with it.  I noticed when I got the system running whenever I unplugged the power cord the CMOS went to defaults and the clock reset.  I took out the motherboard battery and noticed that it was very grungy looking, not shiny like a new one should be.  That is a three volt battery (2032 I believe).  I put my volt meter on it and it read about .5 volts, basically dead.  I replaced the battery and it solved the problem.  I have a background in electronics so this was the type of troubleshooting I was used to, but the average user would have been looking at an RMA situation.  That was obviously and old, used, and dead battery that someone on the Asus assembly line decided to stick into that board.  The box and all packing materials still had the factory seals on them.  One issue I have is that I have had absolutely nothing but trouble out of MSI products.  This goes back well over twenty years so I won't touch them with a ten foot pole.  I've had semi decent luck with Asrock products, but they ain't anything to write home about.  I had used some Gigabyte boards in the past but had trouble out of them as well.  It truly is a rough time to be building PCs these days.
Oh the right to repair argument the manufacturers claim is backfiring on them.  â€œOnly us can fix the ur shitâ€ but your fix is garbage forcing us to buy new.

After starting up a game, in 5 minutes the monitor displayed only No Signal. We tried everything (software) and nothing worked so we decided to RMA the card. We got a brand new card and guess what, the same issue! Later we found out, that the VRM on the card gets so hot that the card just powers off. @JayzTwoCents I am writing you for advice. Here the situation. I have Asus Strix X670E-E Wifi motherboard. Couple weeks ago I tried updating the bios(I bought the rig in January and has not updated since, so that is several versions behind) and right in the middle of the process there was a power failure (in the entire neighbourhood) for 1 second. Just power drop and instant back. Of course this killed my motherboard, error code 00 no boot. This motherboard is equipped with a special bios recovery feature that works without CPU installed or anything, emergency flashback. It has a specially designated USB port and a button. I used it, the bios flashed, no luck. Finally I was able to resurrect the board by removing the bios battery and letting it erase everything. The problems just start here. I THOUGHT the power failure during update messed up something in the hardware, but after this video I think it is the bios itself. The QCode displays every error code possible that ties to RAM. 37, 38, 40, 43, 44, 45, 53, 55, 67, 70, list goes on. And it never stabilizes, always changing. I had really really hard time making the system use EXPO settings (needed several CMOS clears). Aftermath: All is good besides the unstable error codes, no crashes yet. Just 3 things, all in random: Sometimes it fails to boot. I have to take the PC out from the power socket, let me totally depower itself, start again 2.) Sounds disconnects randomly, I have to switch sound output to monitor and back. 3.) Normally games run at 144 FPS. But sometimes they stuck at 15 FPS. Solved by 2-3 restarts All they symptoms kind of tick the list you said you encountered in the video. My config: AMD Ryzen 9 7950 XT AM5 socket, Asus strix RTX 4080, Corsair 1000 W power source (forgot the exact model, modular, gold), 64 GB CL36 Corsair 6000 MT DDR5 RAM, 2 TB Samsung 990PRO SSD  Question: Any chance future bios update solves these (by now minor) issues? Or are these indicators of actual hardware failure from the power outage? PS: The config worked flawlessly until the bios update. But Asus being Asus does not have the old January bios available on the website any more

I've been using ASUS' TUF line for the last... gosh, I want to say 15 years? I always had found their motherboards to be the most stable, most efficient ones on the market. Sure, I paid a premium for maybe 1-2 FPS less, but the stability and peace of mind that came with those was worth far more to me. And when I changed my systems, I would sell my old system at a ridiculously low price to a close friend who's means are far below mine, and the systems all still run to this day. She and her family uses those old ASUS-based computers, one of which is an old 2nd gen i7. Video cards were replaced, RAM was replaced... but the boards were all A-1.  Now? I wonder where I can turn to to have similar stability and quality as the TUF line offered. Because this development really shook my confidence in ASUS' products. I always saw the TUF line as the "highest reliability" line, which is what I'm after. And I guess I'll have to look at other brands whom might offer a similar line... if they do. I've had several Asus laptops where I've needed to apply BIOS updates to fix issues and updating it bricked the machines. Asus each time asked for me to pay more than the cost of the laptop for replacement boards. I've used G.Skill ram in the last, mmm, 8 or 9 years, and had *one* RMA experience with them. Took down my serial number, and shipped me out a replacement under their lifetime warranty. "No, we don't need it back, but you won't be able to RMA the replacement." It was so painless, I kept buying from them... Again, and again, and again... wondering when I'd get the next bad stick. Gigabyte's Ultra Durable lineup are still running -- my eldest is a 1100T hexcore that's still limping along because it just refuses to die. FSP power supplies are another brand that has never let me down. Every penny I spend with Fortron since the FSP-350 from the tomshardware PSU fires article back in ~2002,  I feel I've gotten twofold back in reliability over time. Always overbuilt, always underrated.

Oh man... i waited until the 7800x3d came out to build my new rig.  When it came to the question which mobo i should go for i looked at as much information as i could (at that time the blowing up CPU problem wasn't known yet). I got disappointed quite fast the more i looked into the AM5 boards. They were significantly more expensive with WAY less features to boot. All of them. So i invested more time and settled on this one:  TUF GAMING X670E-PLUS WIFI with: 7800x3d ASUS TUF 3090 32 Gigs of DDR5 5600 28CL (seemed to be the sweetspot with fewer problems on boards) 1TB M.2 (OS) 2TB M.2 2TB SSD (from my old rig) 850 Watt PSU from seasonic (the new vertex one) Arctic Freezer II 360 Lian Li Lancool 216 RGB (non-RGB wasn't avaiable in my country, i'm not a fan of the bling bling)  First up: No fking jokes, i had to restart my pc around 50 times until i got lucky to get into the BIOS. So far so good. Flashed the BIOS to the newest versions with official X3D support (Had to try that 4 times too btw).  Then it wouldn't like Expo until it restarted on its own for like 10 times.  After all of that i "tried" installing Win10. Only had to do it 2 times but it was still annoying af.  Within the first week i had completely random semi freezes of my system while just browsing or idling. If i noticed it happening it was mostly while watching a video. It would start loading as if my internet connection was gone. Then the taskbar would lock up but i could still switch tabs in the browser or steam i.e. After that i wouldn't even be able to get into the taskmanager (so i was never able to see what was causing it) but i would still be able to move the mouse cursor... so semi freezes. No CPU fan ramping up while this was happening or excessive amounts of heat coming out of my rig, it was just locking up as if i had a bad virus on my pc.  Mutliple BIOS updates later and i find myself on the BIOS version 1413 (no Beta version but with the SOC update). System runs pretty stable now or as stable as one would expect. Booting up the system takes like 15-20 minutes. No BSOD since that BIOS version and the voltage for my CPU seems to be locked at 1.25 but i don't have actual measurement tools to confirm the validity of that.  What i do have: The CPU seems to still randomly go into kind of heat mode. I know that 50-60 C aren't bad for the CPU but when it happens while there is no load you start to get itchy in all the wrong places. Gaming is actually quite fine so far but the CPU is getting random heat spikes there too. Since power got expensive here in germany (it starts to normalize to earthly prices now) i locked everything to 60 FPS, sucks when you have 144Hz 27 1440p monitor... two of them but right now that is the best way for my wallet. So as you could guess my PC is bored pretty much always but the CPU still gets weird spikes for no good reason.  So if it helps at all for anybody that also got an ASUS board or the same as mine. The 1413 BIOS version seems to "work" so far without killing the CPU through voltage. Weird behaviour is still there. Asking those moon prices for shit boards is one of the most scummiest things i had the displeasure of experiencing. If your GPU is bad, you RMA that bitch or buy a new one. If your RAM is shit, you RMA it or buy a new one. IF YOUR CPU IS SHIT, it sucks balls but you RMA it or buy a new one.  Now if your Mobo is shit you potentially have to buy a completely new system since everything gets fucked from heaven to hell because the mobo handles EVERYTHING. Fucking fucks.

Yes I've had a 7900X on a Asus X670 Hero since November and its been the most unstable build I've had in a long while. Asus has always been my go to but I will be definitely will be looking at alternatives next time.

14:06 Eh, no? People that knew their shit knew that ASRock always made some of the most reliable and solid motherboards. I haven't been buying ASUS stuff for many years. Their motherboards have been giving me issues. Asrock and MSI boards is what i go with these days.
Courage is rare. I see it in this video.
I'm currently using the ASUS X670E-F, with BIOS 1101 (got that one before they removed it from their site).  With the 7900X3D, and 32GB of 6000Mhz G.SKill Memory.  I only experienced - so far - the following issue: Long boot times whenever I'm _not_ using Optimized Defaults in the BIOS. (I.E., from testing, when I'm on Optimized Defaults, everything works well and the system boots very quickly, so fast - in fact - that I often don't even have the time to press the DEL key quickly enough to even get into the BIOS by the time I already see the Windows screen). However, I haven't had any 'major' problems with it, yet.  Regarding the SoC Voltage situation, without touching any Voltage settings at all, my SoC was detected as being set to 1.394v.  I did read about it about a week ago (this whole thing is relatively new to me but I'm aware of it now). I was surprised, because - then it means - it was defaulted to 1.394v ever since I got the board with my 7900X3D; but somehow and maybe luckily enough nothing blew up and everything is stable (so far anyway).  BUT...  For security reasons, just in case, I apprehensively decided to Manually adjust the SoC Voltage and set it to 1.250v in the BIOS. However, even then it is detected (in the BIOS) as actually being 1.314v, which is weird. But it is lower. And so far, everything remains stable. I might try to keep reducing it a bit until it is detected to be around the 1.200v range, instead. Since I'm pretty sure that it would be enough to run my EXPO2 without any further adjustments.  Basically... I'm crossing fingers because I wouldn't be able to immediately re-afford the purchase the nearly the same components twice. If it DOES 'break', I would first simply move back to my trusty AM4 system I still have (ironically enough, the previous board is still ASUS anyways) with my regular 5800X (non-3D) which ran perfectly fine in terms of stability (and has remained rock solid stable for the 3 or so years I've used it). And if I do have to re-consider another brand then I'm not sure which one I would go with. Maybe Gigabyte or ASRock? I'm not really sure since I've basically always used ASUS boards for the past 15+ years (with the sole exception of one single board from Gigabyte back during the DDR2 years).  I hope that my current system keeps stable and doesn't overheat. And since it's all stable I think I'll just stick with my 1101 BIOS, too.
My random weird issue with my Asus + X3D build is that it no longer recognises my Bluetooth for some reason.  Hopefully it's not something that's broken permanently...
I had to RMA TWO ASUS ROG Maximus XIII Hero boards. The 1st one was a new board but was having a power cycle problem and would never post. Swapped out all other components, still power cycled. Put original components in a "used - acceptable" board from Amazon Warehouse and it posted on 1st power-up. RMA'd it and received a VERY USED board that was scratched, physical issues, and was missing the chipset heatsink. RMA'd that board and received another VERY USED board that had a screw wedged in the VRM headsink, scratches all over, thermal pads chewed up, and the board was bent. Brand new board that was defective and 2 jacked up RMA boards later, I went another route to get a brand new condition board that wasn't defective. I won't be buying any PC components for a while (years), but I'll probably shift to MSI for future builds.
The irony of course is that, as I understand it, Asrock used to be owned by ASUS, but then they broke fully away. Also, many Asrock mbds have actually always been very good, eg. way back, the P55 Deluxe was excellent, and people forget now but the Asrock X58 Extreme6 was very widely used for S1366 CPU/GPU reviews. I've also had only good experiences with two X470 Taichis (both with 2700X), two B450M Pro4s (2600X and 5600X) and an X570 Pro4 with a 5700X.  ASUS was definitely top notch long ago. I have loads of Maximus IV Extreme/Z, Rampage IV Extreme, P9X79/E WS and the venerable Striker II Extreme (among others), so seeing them slide in this way is sad.  And indeed, for most newer builds I've opted for MSI, namely  a B450 Tomahawk Max II + 5600X for a gaming platform upgrade, several more for benchmarking. It's as if the whole market rep spectrum has flipped round; MSI didn't used to be that good, but they've climbed to the top aswell (sans the occasional blip as HU has covered).  Is it yet another case of somehow PR/marketing in these companies telling engineering what to do? If so then that's completely insane.

ASUS is a joke now. Several years on and the fan control on two Crosshair VI Hero (X370) systems I have still completely breaks if hardware monitoring utilities try to poke the EC at the wrong time. For some reason it's only fixable if you go into the BIOS and make one of those configuration changes that causes the board to turn off and then back on when you save settings and exit--I think they're doing something weird like saving the configuration and state for the EC that controls the fans next to the microcode configuration data that gets updated when you swap CPUs. Not even clearing CMOS fixes it; it HAS to be a change to one of the options that makes the board power off and back on. Pretty sure my STRIX X570-E does the same thing, but I just stopped letting utilities talk to the controller because the issue it causes is such a pain in the ass. I think these will be my last ASUS boards. I miss ABIT and DFI, or even Gigabyte 15 years ago. One time I RMA'd a board with a blown trace to Gigabyte, but after voiding my warranty someone repaired the board by hand before sending it back because they thought it would be fun! Fond memories of a world that no longer exists.
I don't think it's all that bad. Give it some break. The issue with burning Ryzens is on all AM5 mobo makers not just ASUS. I'm with a GIGABYTE X670E AORUS MASTER and a 7950X3D. And have been updating the UEFI as soon as a new one comes out. But i've not touched anything in the BIOS and have been using the Defaults with only the Preffered Cores set to Cache. Even my RAM is at 4800MHz CL40 defaults. And it's all because i'm willing to wait this problem out till it goes completely away with new BIOSes. So i think it's all of the mobo makers fault for not following AMD's orders on how a BIOS should work. Stop bashing ASUS. They were the first ones to act on the issue matter.

Wow that's saddening. Here is my story. I had my own IT business in South Africa back in 2003. Had provided a customer just over 200 systems running an Asus a7n8x-e deluxe board. Within a month 8 had failed. My supplier refused to replace saying i had built them incorrectly, so i got hold of asus directly. As they didnt have a technical facility in SA, they hired a local specialist to come and have a look. He did some investigation and confirmed board failure. This all took another 2 months and additional 35-ish board fails. Based on local engineers finding,Asus flew out one of their own specialist to dig deeper on the issue along with temporary replacement systems for my customer. In the end it was identified that the boards had a major issues. In total around 140 of them were faulty. Asus provided a full replacement of boards and rrp refund for my purchase as an apology. THIS IS CUSTOMER SERVICE. I've used Asus ever since. Please return to this level of care Asus. I dont want to turn away from you but might have to if this is now your level of customer care.

When I was going through problems with a new build just a little over a year ago. I was trying to pin point where my problem was. One potential solution was a beta bios version with the same clause. I refused to use it because if my motherboard was actually shot I'd be throwing it away and my money. Long story short, it was actually my cpu and it took putting in a different cpu just to test and prove it.   The RMA process with AMD was even less fun. They wanted me to put the bad chip back into the system and continue to run tests I already had been running for months. In the end, I had to take pictures of the bad cpu in the motherboard along with an ID code for the ticket to be visible with the motherboard id visible in the same picture. I went a step further and took pictures of the good cpu in the same and made it clear in the pictures using a photo edit to label in the image which was the bad cpu and the good cpu. Cause I didn't want to let them get it wrong. AMD did take care of me though and I am very happy having a chip that works. The original chip had a bad memory controller.

They still asked me what I done to resolve the issue despite the fact I already answered the questions they asked me in each email I received.  After a few days back and forth I got very fed up of the bs and demanded a replacement or refund. I told them in not such a nice manner that I already gave them all the details they needed and more , more than once and they were still asking me to do it again.  They went to the manager and gave me a replacement with an apology.  Another company who I bought a steering wheel from was just as bad. The first one the thing died after six weeks so in the RMA email I sent I told them everything that was happening with video proof.   It took them ten days to reply and they proceeded to ask me what I had done and what to do to try to resolve the issue. Which I already told them what I done. It took them a few days to respond after I once again told them what I done to resolve the issue. They then asked for pictures or video proof which I already sent them so I re sent it to them. Every single email was as jay said condescending bs for a month before they replaced the wheel.   Then a month later the power supply for the wheel died so I had to go through it again. And when they sent me a replacement they sent me a used unit.  The replacement wheel lasted three months before it stopped self calibrating so once again I had to go through the ringer again but it took longer to get a replacement because they were accusing me of intentionally breaking the wheel. I didn't get the second replacement for free either.  So I decided to move on to Logitech because I wasn't going to deal with such a company again.

How can I make sure that it is my MB that is at fault here and not just a bad CPU? I had suspicions that my Z690 Strix DDR4 WiFi was... Acting up to say the least.  My 12700K bluescreened on me almost daily before I turned off any and all optimisations except XMP. I disabled everything that said "controlled by BIOS" or set it to "intel default". I checked temps with HW64 but the apparent issue is voltage control when the cores start boosting from idle - especially E cores. So I went into the BIOS and set up Vdroop and such to OC levels without actually doing any OC. Since then it runs stable, but I always wondered if it's because of my MB, cooling, PSU or, as far as Asus weird SP score goes, a bad CPU that can't take any OC at all. From checking with either manufacturers, I had no reason for RMA so far as it's not determinable where it comes from, but I also don't have the money to get another MB to test it. It also takes way too much time as I could do it.  Is there an easy way I just missed or is ASUS whole AI-Bios stuff so insanely unstable that I shouldn't expect it to work at all? Isn't that what I paid for?

I built a new AMD PC 2 months ago, and let me tell you I didn't even think of going Asus for some reason. I was locked in to go the MSI route from the get-go, and seeing this now I'm so happy I did so. The only ASUS piece of hardware I got was my keyboard (TUF GAMING K3), and that was only because I couldn't find the Steel Series that I initially wanted. Seeing this right now makes me so glad I didn't even think of going with Asus. The X3D CPU's is a very unique series of processors which seems to be too much for some of the motherboards out there, and that mainly has to do with how the motherboards are programmed, the BIOS, software, etc. Most of the accidents involving X3D processors are mainly caused because of overclocking BS, or instability with voltages (also subject to overclocking), and bad bios, and/or bad software, optimization specifically regarding the X3D processors. Same sh*t had happened with some 5800X3D's where some mor*ns were literally trying to overclock it just because the motherboard's overclocking feature was not programmed to lock out with processors of that series. In all honesty, that is the fault of these people. However, as manufacturer YOU ARE OBLIGATED to have your products and/or software optimized for any circumstances you might encounter. So, although some of these accidents are the fault of the owners, the manufacturers could have avoided that, if they could've released specific bios, and/or software, to accommodate this specific series of processors. So, all in all you are 100% right, but let's not downplay the st*pidity of some people out there, especially in this day and age when everyone is just doing all kinds of st*pid sh*t just to put it on the internet and make some rounds online. Same people who are now probably stuck with tens of PS5's crying in a corner because they can't sell their scalped products anymore. I don't feel sorry for these people, but the rest of us don't have to put up with that sh*t. So, yeah Asus needs some extended corner time to think and reflect on all their BS.

I've started seeing the signs back before the Skylake Intel CPUs.  My 4790k had the turbo settings cranked up excessively on the Asus H81 motherboard it was on. I know, should be on a Z97 board, but 1-was building an ITX build, 2- the only Z97 itx mobo was long gone and 3- Asus had this model shipped with the bios for Haswell Refresh support included.  Problem is, even on a beefy cooler, it would spike the temps to 100 and force my PSU to fire off the OVP (Only realized that after I fixed the issue). Turns out undervolting the turbo values and amps managed to have it run cooler but also at the full turbo speeds advertised without stability issues. Before I did that fix in the bios I tried a bios update but the problem persisted after the update.  The Scar II laptop isn't safe from criticism as well. The battery manages to last less than 10 seconds when older laptops that I have managed to at least hold on for a couple minutes. Also the SD card reader won't read perfectly working cards and I found out many others face the same issue. I've been an Asus fan boy admittedly for years. I had maximus boards, prime boards, my son's build has a stix b450 and my prime x470 pro board finally started to show signs it needed to be replaced. Having a 5900x I wanted an x570 dark hero. I couldn't get one anywhere. I needed a board quick so the closest in spec was the MSI MEG X570s Ace Max. I ordered it and it looked great and had everything I needed. So I built it and I had the same issues with audio drops, that you had and crackling and it was system latency. It took several calls and remote assistance from focusrite for my audio interface, emails to MSI and gigabyte for my GPU and motherboard to try and fix the issue. Then on the 28th of march I think, MSI released the AGESA update for my board that addressed an FTPM issue causing latency spikes. The work around was to get a dedicated tpm module and disable bitlocker, set the bios to read the dedicated tpm module instead of the built in FTPM and all would be well. Although I could not source, neither could my retailer, a tpm chip to fit my board anywhere. So I updated the new bios and the problem was still there and I sent it back and my retailer tested it and confirmed the fault and refunded me. So I went to, Asus UK website and they showed the dark hero in stock, while waiting for my refund, I ordered the dark hero. I called Asus to make sure it was in fact in stock and they said yes, it will be with you in a couple of days. Brilliant. Came off the call and 10 minutes later I got a call back saying sorry. The warehouse has just informed me we don't have any dark heroes in stock. Oh, well do you have any x570 boards. No we don't have any what so ever so we will refund you. Great so waiting for 2 refunds, I find a Cross hair formula VIII x570 and it comes and I install it. Then my 360 copelix AIO dies with pump failure and flashes red. Ok RMA and ordered a new one and I have a copelix xt pro. So all working now and my system is beautifully stable with the 5900x at 4.75ghz all core and decent temps. What I will say is out of the box the system latency was so much better using LatencyMon to track it. The AGESA update was implemented much better than msi's but needed some tweaking to get it right down. Nvidia drivers are terrible for spikes with their drivers and believe me when I say I tried everything from core affinities, priorities, power plans, and enabling and disabling drivers, use of processor lasso, all the way to quantum timing to get my system to a point where it can handle real time audio properly. This was an AMD issue but Asus boards seem to handle it better in my experience but I completely agree with your video and justification to boycott Asus for now and they have been terrible on the new tech boards. I was thinking of buying a new x670, 7950x and upgrading my ram and would have gone Asus had I not watched yours, and Steve's videos before hand. Asus has gone down hill so much. It's great having an aesthetically pleasing motherboard but absolutely useless if it's blowing things up, catching fire. A dirty move with the beta bios. Voiding warranty to reduce rma's and people suing for other components damaged. It's drawing you in with a fix that doesn't fix and voiding your warranty at the same time relinquishing Asus from responsibility. A very dirty move! I'm glad my system is stable and working, being a previous generation but feel sorry for anyone who has had issues and is facing this fight with Asus. Very bad form indeed!

All the way from high end ROG, to WS to lower end boards, all fails and have very poor QC with notoriously bad fix-pipeline (Aka, the lack of it). Asus Firmwares and updates are following the good old riddle:  99 little bugs in the code! 99 little bug in the code! Take one down Patch it around 256 little bugs in the code.
Regarding the memories, it seems that this problem is solved with certified memories for the AMD platform. They could be the same kitt, one Intel and the other AMD and it seems that the Intel kitt doesn't work and gives stability problems. If you switch to the same Amd certified kit, all problems miraculously disappear. We didn't have this problem on the AM4 platform but it seems that times are different now.

thanks Jay
I had to drop ASUS back when the ryzen 1 launched.  I use linux.  I early adopted ryzen and put together a system with nvme and an asus board.  I knew to expect some growing pains.  Right off the bat the CSM setting that allows you to boot non-commercial OSs in UEFI/GPT mode didn't work correctly, and it had to in order to use the nvme for some reason I don't remember now.  I didn't get mad.  I could install, but not boot.  I knew it was a software problem.  I called to report that there was an issue and see if maybe they had a dev firmware with that issue solved.  I got immediately told that they design the boards and AMD designs their processors expressly and only to run on windows technology.  I really don't know how to teach people that software development actually follows hardware development overwhelmingly, and only some provisioning is done in hardware to allow certain standards that software uses to function.  They don't seem to understand that the hardware or a hardware standard comes first, then software is developed around it for 99.8% of all instances.  I explained that I write software, and what I was asking for was not some crazy new feature, but an industry standard feature that they claimed to support.  They came back with they can't help me troubleshoot linux.  I explained that the issue was the UEFI firmware not correctly supporting an industry standard feature and I was reporting it and just trying to see if they had an update in the works yet.  It was essentially trying to force the commercial key use when booting from the nvme, but not the live image.  To top that off, if you installed to a sata ssd, the nvme drive was not visible for whatever reason.  I got hung up on.  I calmed down and called back after a few minutes.  Re-explained everything and got told after two hours of support fumbling while I tried to remain calm (the machines are my passion, probably not the support guy's thing) that all I had to do was install the drivers first, then I could install the OS....  really?  I tried (a bit sarcastically, but trying to obviously joke so he could see where the issue was) to offer the guy a fin ($5 bill) if he could show me how to install his windows drivers, without windows, on bare metal, and use them to install linux.  It was very funny, not funny, but I don't believe in being abusive to phone staff, they usually have a bad enough day 11 out of 9 times.  I've had those jobs too, once upon a time.  There was a lot more to these discussions, but yeah, I was done.  I was very upset because they were the followup to old Abit.  Been using asrock, gigabyte, and msi since.  A little more difficult to find the exact product I want, but it has gotten a lot better over the time that has passed.  I still have and use the nvme (a samsung pro device) and it works fine without any errors.  I wound up giving the machine (sans my nvme) to my wife who uses windows,  and going with a taichi.
Good thing we went MSI for our last build. Sheer luck but it's been great so far!

message to ASUS you have lost me as a potential customer,
I rarely leave comments, but this time I felt compelled to share my thoughts.  For over a decade, I've relied exclusively on Asus motherboards due to their unparalleled stability and exceptional build quality. In the past, I experimented with Gigabyte and MSI motherboards, only to be disappointed by their performance and eventual failure. However, my faith in Asus is beginning to waver.  Recently, I invested approximately 4000 Euros in new parts, including an Asus Crosshair 670e Extreme motherboard, primarily for its integrated 10Gbit network. I paired it with a 7950x3D CPU, my first x3D CPU ever. I was incredibly thrilled and even stood in line on launch day, making me one of the first in Sweden to own it. Unfortunately, my experience has been far from satisfactory. Since day one, I have encountered numerous issues with this setup, and I am on the verge of replacing the motherboard to determine if the problem lies with Asus. While I understand that being an early adopter comes with risks, the extent of the problems I've faced is extraordinary, especially considering my history with high-end systems. Random BSODs and overall instability plague my system, although it has improved slightly with the 1410 bios, which, incidentally, has invalidated my warranty. Fortunately, Swedish consumer rights laws are robust, and I doubt I will encounter any difficulties returning the board to my local retailer, Webhallen.  This whole situation has piqued my curiosity. I have followed your channel since its inception and have often relied on your recommendations for my builds because they have proven to be reliable. As an enthusiast who always seeks the absolute best regardless of cost, I implore you to delve deeper into this issue instead of resorting to an easy fix by switching to Intel. I urge you to try a different motherboard at home for a while and observe if it improves your situation. I am genuinely intrigued!  Furthermore, I have concerns about a less apparent issue: CPU degradation. I manually set my SOC voltage to 1.2V and have fine-tuned my system to achieve stable performance, now with EXPO enabled. However, I worry if this bios issues have the potential to cause long-term damage to my CPU, which may not be immediately noticeable but could manifest one or two years from now, possibly after the warranty has expired. I've noticed that my boost frequencies have suffered and may be lower than what should be considered normal for a 7950x3D CPU. What would you consider a typical boost frequency for this CPU model?

I recently upgraded my PC from 2018 which had an ASUS ROG Strix board. I have no particular brand loyalties although I had a shocking experience for Gigabyte in 2018. Prior to my purchases of my computer components I scanned all merchant websites, Reddit and forums for reviews and experience with ASUS and other products including intel and AMD (my previous system was AMD). I slowly noticed a pattern as Jay pointed out there: DOA boards, used boards sent to customers instead of new within 30 day period, reversed capacitors, missing components. Hence I pulled the trigger on an MSI board and an intel system (also noticed some issues with AMD using same analysis).   My advice is: Do not have a brand loyalty also if something worked for you before check if they have been consistent since last time you used them. Remember most of us have an upgrade cycle 3-5 years and a lot can change in that time.
