A laptop of mine kept on degrading in performance to the most sluggish, unusable thing imaginable. I'm not exaggerating, I mean it ran like a Windows 98 computer riddled with viruses.   My brother has a degree in computer science and I know a fair bit myself. We did everything we could that didn't void warranty to try and diagnose and fix the problem. I was at university at the time (in halls) so it took a very long time and it was extremely inconvenient. The best solution was to format and start over, but you had about a week before it would degrade back again. Edit: Oh I forgot to mention that the week window of "it runs better" got smaller and smaller over time. It worked as it should the first day and then got worse and worse the following days, but eventually it was it ran as it should the first hour and then got worse and worse.  Once I got home, I contacted ASUS for RMA and I told them we think its the motherboard. I told them everything we did to diagnose and try and fix the problem, and I told them how many times I had formatted the laptop.   So it went into RMA and it came back... and degraded back again. All they did was format.   I complained again, telling them the issue won't be fixed with a format and expressed how many times we had done that. It was took into RMA and formatted and returned.   I complained again and it was took into RMA, formatted and returned.   It was absolutely ridiculous. All they had to do was replace the motherboard and test it. Even if we were wrong and it wasn't the motherboard (unlikely), they should have done some part swapping at that point  In the end I got a refund.

Asus has been quality scum for a while. I have a prime x470 pro board and there is a known issue with cura slicer and a few other programs that completely crashes PCs when those programs are running. Cause is the Mainboard failing to switch C-states but still attempting to do so. I have been in contact with Asus support for months until they finally admitted that this issue is widespread and that they would forward it to their engineers in Taiwan. They said they would get back to me in about 2 weeks. It has been 2 years. This is a full system crash issue. Not even windows crash. That explains why the C-states cause problems. When entering C-states, the voltage drops, and it then rings. The ringing voltage causes the CPU to lock up. To prevent that issue, you have to disable C-states.

Oh man, I know what you feel. I had a couple of new boards with bent pins and it is extremely hard to prove who is to blame :( Here is my story with Asus which is still ongoing :( I work in a company that rents gaming computers. Last year we built a fleet of a 110 brand new PCs with 12700K/32GB RAM/Asus RTX 3070Ti TUF OC. We got the card recommendation from Asus representative who helped us with our prices/shipping etc. and he knew exactly how are we using the computers which means they are made for travel in special cases with wheels and foam inside. We always took their Dual (150 pcs) series but since we wanted to make more premium looks we went with TUF series. Of course such big cards had to be properly supported so we took Lian LI Anti sag brackets that are simple and stealthy. After the first come back from an event that took around 3 months I had to sent over 25 cards for RMA. We contacted Asus and they told us its not possible and we sure were mining on them!! That was the sign that they are starting to back up from every responibility and we had to explain to them that these GPUs were sitting in computers and traveling from one event to another. Turns out their (GPUs) quality is so low that they start to bend during the shipping even with addition anti sag bracket (go look JayZTwoCents video about GPU sag and check for Asus and you will know what i mean). It has been almost a year and I sent them over 60 cards with unique serial numbers and many of them went over 2-3 times for RMA. Since we are a company and not end customer we cant simply return them so the game is still going. Anyway, whoever is dealing with Asus right now I wish you all the best because lately it was a nightmare

Sigh...the disclaimer says "we cannot guarantee this BIOS works, we're pretty sure it does, but there's a chance it could fail; we're not forcing you to update, if you choose to do so, you do so understanding the risk." It's there because people are too stupid to know what a beta version is. Nowhere does it say anything about voiding your warranty or that you will no longer receive support for the product if you use it. Not sure why nobody seems to understand this. Also not sure why nobody is mentioning Gigabyte or MSI, whose boards are also burning up the 7xxxX3D CPUs for the same apparent issues (which points to a larger issue with the design of the AM5 socket)...MSI also released a beta BIOS to the public, without any warning/disclaimer attached, while Gigabyte literally has "updating your BIOS is risky, we strongly suggest you don't do it unless you're having problems on your current version" as their advice for the issue, yet nobody's saying anything about either of them. Why is that? By all means, blast Asus for the poor QC and support (especially that dumbass "just turn EXPO off" statement they made), but if you're gonna blast one company for it, don't turn a blind eye towards the others that are doing the same thing.

This is unfortunate (for ASUS), but also validating for me. Our wee computer repair shop has just a few brands (or sometimes branch of a brand) on our "suspect" list where if someone's having a major issue, and a suspect could MAYBE cause that symptom, we start by ruling out that part first. Saves us so much time. I'm just the admin assistant, and had very little computer knowledge when I started. I wanted to like ASUS, but our repair tech just shook his head, "No, they're only about looks and hype." After building with a variety of boards at different price points over just the last couple of years, I'd come to the same conclusion (I handle new computer sales). Also, their laptops leave something to be desired when it comes to longevity and reparability (statistically in our shop, anyway). We usually lean toward Gigabyte or MSI depending on the build (I know Gigabyte gets a hard wrap when doing an AMD build, but their BIOS options are the most straightforward and tweakable for Intel CPUs that we've seen, IMO). When building tower servers, we usually have ASUS motherboards, but I'd be lying if we didn't just yesterday retire an entire server because the freaking motherboard died. Like WTF when does that happen in a server, especially one less than 10 years old??  When it comes to RMA, we've had customers have to RMA MSI and Gigabyte for this or that, and it's always been smooth. (Like MSI pump going out, or Gigabyte board needing a new CPU socket because PINs.) For us, how easy it is to handle a defective product is more important than pretty much anything else. For instance, Silicon Power SATA SSD's: not super fast, but they are super cheap, and their RMA process cannot be beat. We track percentage of failures and set our customers up with back-ups, and with hundreds of drives sold, RMA rate hovers around 3%. We choose them for our average mom or pop with an 10-year-old HDD who needs their computer to just work again. We like Western Digital but getting through the RMA process is like pulling teeth, and a bad batch of SA510's have soured us to their blue SATA SSDs (rebranded Sandisk??). I gave up last time I had to RMA RAM to Crucial; zero response. Corsair wants you to run Memtest and then they're like, BAM new RAM for you. Samsung is also pretty decent on RMA, didn't even give us a hard time when a drive only needed a firmware update to fix I/O, and we couldn't smash it into the Magician software right.  I could go on, but, I'm up past my bedtime obviously. Sorry only 10% of this post was on topic. D:
Well that's a turn for the worse. I did my last build around 3 years ago with ASUS and haven't had any issues.  It's sad to see that the company fall so quickly into just another tech company fleecing its customers. Good to see a strong moral stand from the JayzTwoCents team.

Part of me is super disappointed by ASUS's fall from grace but the other part of me feels super vindicated. When I was first really starting to get into PCs, something seemed really pretentious about ASUS and I avoided them because I just felt like they would be super condescending if I ever had a problem. (Turns out that was true.) While I'm not big on the ultra-gaudy esthetic, I ended up going with MSI for my first dip into PC gaming and got one of their laptops. After a couple of years, I was ready to get my first desktop but wasn't ready to DIY. I'd heard about how reliable ASUS was so when I found a prebuilt with an ASUS motherboard, I bought it and an ASUS monitor. Those things were rock solid. They still actually work (that whole PC does tbh) and it's being turned into an HTPC/NAS hybrid machine. I still use the monitor too. Since I had such a great experience with ASUS on the old PC, I figured I would be safe to use them for my new PC and got a 3090ti and a combo deal for a 12th gen Intel and ASUS motherboard at MicroCenter a few months back. They've all been super solid so far and I was really looking forward to having a really reliable brand to trust. I figured that my gut was finally wrong for once and ASUS actually wasn't taking the scenic route to Scamville but here we are in Scamville after all... Well, ASUS got lucky by getting a few solid purchases from me and I got lucky by not having issues yet. I'm happy to stop betting here.  The whole ASRock thing unearthed a long lost memory for me though. My dad got really into computers before I was born and even had a leadership position in a PC users club of sorts. (Thinking about that feels really weird now. It'd be like creating an IRL, local group with a permanent meeting space leased out and everything for discussing AI and ChatBots and such lmao.) He was still tinkering with PCs well into my teens before technology started improving way too quickly for him to keep up as he got older. He used to bring home ASRock products and mess with them to try and figure out why they were so bad. He passed away a couple of years ago and I'm only now going through his home office. I found some old, broken ASRock things just the other day, along with a ton of other older tech. Man was a horder but so am I and none of that stuff is ever leaving, even if it is junk. No, I technically don't need five (5) 3.5" floppy disks that, all together, make one boot copy of Windows NT3.1 or the Lian-Li hot-swap hard drive bay that's older than I am... But they're cool. Plus, he had at least 2 broken 5.25" internal CD drives and I've been needing some cupholders for my desk.
In regards of a rampage vi extreme, I am still waiting for improvements on the aura sync, is a shame their quality assurance for product support.
Guess I'm buying ASrock for my next build.

Amen Bro!!!
To start,  I've used ASUS for decades. I decided to build a home server and chose ASUS, which was a horrible choice. the motherboard I chose was picked specifically had 3 16x physical PCIe slots. I put a 5600 cpu and 64GB of Gskill 2333MHz memory into it. The machine could not run proxmox and trueNAS. So I built a 2nd server for trueNAS thinking i had a compatibility issue.  Even with just proxmox it was still having weird, random issues until i updated the bios. The machine was fairly stable. until one day it said one of the cpu's was locked. I figured that I'd reboot to check that the bios wasn't weird from the update a few weeks earlier.  this is when i found that the USB keyboard was not recognized during post. luckily i had an old PS2 keyboard that mostly worked (some keys weren't recognized, like the main enter key). I was now able to enter the bios, but the USB mouse didn't work.  i started talking to ASUS support about no USB  detection during post, but as soon as the OS started to load the keyboard and mouse would work. Every single CSR tech blamed my issue on the cpu, then ram, then hdd, then the keyboard and mouse.  i had to complain to a supervisor to get an RMA.  after we realized that i couldn't reload the bios because of no USB. I asked for an advanced replacement but was told there was no stock. I bought an ASRock motherboard so i could return the ASUS motherboard. When the ASRock motherboard arrived I moved all the hardware to that motherboard, except the NVMe standoff fell off the ASUS motherboard. I could see no damage, so I put a tiny amount of glue on the standoff (ASUS had originally glued it to the motherboard, I'd never seen that before). Before I returned the ASUS motherboard I tested it and it was still able to recognize and boot from the NVMe.  I then moved all the hardware to the ASRock motherboard which ran flawlessly (including the USB).  I again asked for an advanced replacement, but was told there was no stock. The next day I shipped the motherboard back, with all everything that came with it.  A few days later I got an email from ASUS informing me that they couldn't repair my motherboard as I had damaged the NVMe standoff. I contacted multiple people fighting this over some weeks.  I explained what had happened. I just wanted them to at least try to put a bios that worked. They refused. Everytime ASUS contacts you, they say that there will be a response in 48 hours. That is a lie, they NEVER respond.   When I got an email saying that I had to pay for the repairs (the invoice showed that I would be charged for a new motherboard, a repair fee and return shipping)  or it would be returned, I demanded to talk to a supervisor. I was told that the RMA department did not have a supervisor. Multiple more email complaints and I got a response from a RMA supervisor. It was always "you damaged the motherboard, we can't fix it".  I then asked to talk to a manager. Multiple emails demanding that I talked to a manager and one day I got a phone call from someone at ASUS informing me that a manager would be calling me with in 48 hours.  Not only didn't a manager call me, I got a "final warning" about my motherboard, saying that if I didn't pay for a replacement that my motherboard would be replaced. Within hours I sent an email saying not to send my motherboard back while I am still waiting to speak with a manager.  2 days later, my original motherboard arrived. It was in a white box and did not include anything that I sent them. I string of further complaints to corporate and I got a response from a supervisor. The new offer was a "discount" from the full MSRP of the motherboard. I told them I didn't want to pay more for a replacement motherboard, plus repair fees and shipping than I paid for the original motherboard.   Eventually someone from corporate contacted me. I asked her why I couldn't get an advanced replacement, but as soon as my motherboard arrived at ASUS suddenly there was a motherboard available, 2 days later. She claimed that it wasn't different stock. The motherboards at RMA can't be used for advanced replacement. This is when I found that ASUS wanted me to pay full MSRP, repair fees, and shipping for a "repaired" RMA motherboard. I was also told that the RMA department throws out the manuals and accessories because they don't have room for them. She had no reason why ASUS forces customers to send all of that and pay extra to ship it if the RMA department is going to throw it all away.   After weeks of fighting, I finally gave in. She had agreed to a huge discount, no repair fees, no shipping and ASUS would pay my shipping. I figured it was worth it just to have a spare on my shelf. I insisted that I got a NEW motherboard, not a refurbished one and that the new motherboard's warranty be extended to the date it arrived plus some for my troubles.  No one that I spoke to cared that I have been buying and recommending ASUS for years. They didn't care that I used to sell their products. I think that the only reason they gave me a replacement motherboard was because I posted my experience on their facebook page where thousands saw it.  Guess when I'll buy another ASUS product?  They sure were not on the list of contenders for my gaming laptop that I bought last November.   All they had to do was turn the motherboard on, put a new bios on it and see if the USB would work. They refused to do it, even if I sent my motherboard back a 2nd time.   15 minutes of a tech's time could have saved decades long customer.   Except, they didn't have stock on the motherboard. She offered a different one that didn't have 3x physical PCIe slots. I found a motherboard that was a bit higher priced that had the 3 PCIe slots. I offered to buy that one and pay the difference and was told that that was impossible.  this is the tldr; version. I condensed the horror story as much as i could if not too much.

I've been building systems since 1993 and used to swear by Asus for not only my personal rigs but for my clients as well. Built a lot of industrial PCs, Non-gaming PCs and Gaming PCs all withh Asus motherboards and GPUs. I was quite the fanboy up until the last batch of workstations I built for a local medium sized business around 2014 began to fail, one after another. They were 4th gen 1150 boards with the Intel B85 chipset. Built 12 PCs for the company and within 6 mo. all but 2 failed with dead motherboards. 1 failed about a year in and the last one is still running today, surprisingly. Before that, I had only had one other Asus MB fail between 1993 and 2014. Switched to MSI for MBs and GPUs and haven't had any failures yet. Companies change hands, management changes, people that actually cared about the product and the consumer leave/retire etc. Still, it's a shame to see what used to be an awesome brand die. C'est la vie though, I guess.

Asus was my go to for every component that they made when I built my first desktop in 2013 or so (Z87 chipset TUF mobo w/ i5 4590, Asus 1070 GPU) due to excellent quality and stability I got from my gaming series laptops I had bought from them before. My next PC was built at the tail end of 2nd gen Ryzen, right before 3rd gen was launched. chose the strix X-470F board paired with a 2700X,  since I still felt Asus was quality. My friend ended up picking up almost identical parts to me after I showed him my build. My build was like the devil PC. Random crashes in certain games constantly. His build was rock solid, out of frustration I ended up replacing different components over the next year to iron out the issues since I spent hours troubleshooting and swapping parts. The final change was the MOBO. Went to the ASRock steel legend B550. Followed by a change to a 3800XT CPU shortly after, but the 2700X was stable once the Mobo was changed. I would have written that experience off had I not done a ton of reading and learning about components in my quest to get my PC stable. After seeing the quality of Asus's parts go way downhill and seeing other people's experience with Asus support. I had already decided my next build would use ASRock or gigabyte Mobo. I did recently upgrade to the AM5 platform, I went with the 7900X and strix B650E combo micro center had for a ridiculously good price with the bundled Gskill ram. I really wanted the ASRock steel legend B650E Mobo, and considered leaving the strix sealed and selling it, and now I wish I had. I can say my system is very stable though, i updated my bios to the one they had released right before the X3D compatible one as I built my system a few weeks before the X3D's were available and flashed to the latest bios before ever installing windows. I was able to run the Gskill 6000 kit on expo 2 settings no issue, but hopefully my CPU didn't get damaged. I never paid attention to my SOC voltage levels as I just turned on Pb2 and left everything on auto untill I had time to do the negative offset curve optimizer tuning. I just updated my bios and still run expo 2, SOC voltage is safe, and I set up an 85C temp limit, -30 curve optimizer, 180PPT, 480TDC, 640EDC profile and it has been stable, so I'm sure I can undervolt it even more if I want to spend the time.

I don't really mess around too much with LGA platforms but doesn't the PGA socket seem more safe? I mean, yeah there's a bunch of pins on the CPU that could get damaged but at least there's a sort of plastic housing on the mainboard for all the pins to slot into. LGA just seems to be... free floating? to some degree, just seems very fragile. I mean I know it works but damn, if there were some support substrate between each pin, seems like it would be a lot less prone to damage.

I don't always agree with Jay but the one thing I agree with him is an important point he touched upon in this video: the problem is not really about the language that ASUS used regarding beta BIOS - as Jay said, beta BIOSes have existed for millennia, and they are beta because they haven't been tested as thoroughly as final release.  The important thing is beta BIOSes are often for stuffs that aren't as serious. Regarding the SoC voltage of the current issue, that is very serious stuff. I would expect that to be covered under warranty that is worth any salt.  I don't want beta BIOSes to go away. I don't want the suits in ASUS to say "we ain't doing beta BIOSes from now on". I think beta BIOSes have a place in the world.

Back in 2017, I got an Asus ROG laptop to run CAD software for school; it is solid as a rock and is honestly still going strong today. When I went to build myself my first custom tower, I went with an Asus B650 motherboard because of my prior good experience with Asus products. Let me tell you, I did not have a good experience with their product this time around. The board I received was evidently defective upon arrival because the m.2 standoff sheared off the board with me just screwing it on (which they then proceeded to immediately deny my RMA for "user-induced damage") due to what I guess is faulty soldering. Furthermore, after completing the build, my system had such extreme memory instability that it frequently would not boot, or stay on for at most 15 minutes before entering a fit of BSODs (diagnosing this was extremely tricky because Asus also cheaped out and didn't include any form of debug LED on the board). In the end, I ended up swapping it out for an AsRock motherboard and my system has been stable and functional ever since. I am extremely disappointed and frustrated with Asus now, I company I used to respect, and because of this experience I decided to swear off of any other Asus product in the future. It's comforting to see that I'm not alone in this experience and not being extreme in deciding to not do business with them going forward. Thanks for being a beacon of honesty and responsibility in the face of Asus's behavior, Jay, it means a lot to the little guys like us!

ASRock was originally spun off from Asus in 2002 in order to compete with companies like Foxconn for the commodity OEM market. Since then, ASRock has also gained momentum in the DIY sector and plans for moving the company upstream began in 2007 following a successful IPO on the Taiwan Stock Exchange.[3] It was acquired by Pegatron in 2010.[4]  As of 2011, ASRock is the world's third largest motherboard manufacturer,[5] having cooperated with professional esports player Johnathan Wendel in the development of a gaming-oriented enthusiast motherboard in 2011.[citation needed]  ASRock established itself as a server motherboard affiliate in April 2013, having received orders from 10 mid-size clients for server and industrial PC motherboards and forming partnerships with system integrators.[6]

Jay, I walked away from ASUS back in the Athlon 900 days for customer service issues. Been through _two_ MSI boards (790FX-GD70) that patently refused to run my Sapphire RX580 Nitro+ (blue model) at PCIe x16 - I could only ever get them to run at x8. MSI blamed it on me. and when I finally upgraded to an R7 2700x platform, the long derided ASROCK Taichi x470 had the best reviews and exactly the feature set I wanted.   Yes, I've RMA'd the Taichi board, but I also RMAd the Corsair Vengeance RAM and the original Ryzen R7 2700 (non-x) because of what turned out to be a failure of the memory controller on the CPU. _ALL THREE_ brands were happy to work with me and AMD even replaced my R7 2700 with an R7 2700x _under warranty_ two months after the warranty expired because I could show an 18 month long  chain of events trying to diagnose the problem.  So yeah, while ASRock may have began life as a "budget ASUS", their customer service is far better than their parent company. Yeah, ASRock may not have all the bells and whistles that ASUS does and may have lower-tier specs compared to other brands, but the fact of the matter is that _their products work exactly as advertised._ and do so at a lower price point.   My current system is an ASRock Taichi x470, R7 2700x, 32G Corsair Vengeance RAM at 2900 (mismatched pairs, so it's my own damn fault they can't go faster), Sapphire RX580 Nitro+ SE. I get 60-90 FPS in CP2077 with custom 'low' settings, 65-100+ in Scum, and similar in Elite: Dangerous and No Mans Sky. I'm very happy with the system.

Regrettably, I experienced the same issues as Jay did. Towards the end of 2021, I purchased an ASUS ROG STRIX Z590-E motherboard, only to discover that one of the m.2 slots was defective. I recorded a video of the setup to demonstrate the issue and requested a replacement for the brand new motherboard I had purchased. However, I was only offered a refurbished motherboard, which I reluctantly accepted.  I went through the RMA process and was assured that I would receive a replacement motherboard, which was eventually shipped to me. However, after several weeks had passed without receiving the replacement, I reached out to support once more. To my surprise, they claimed that the CPU pin was bent and that I was not entitled to a refund. I was baffled by this response, as I had only requested a replacement for the faulty m.2 slot, not a refund.  I had to engage in a lengthy exchange of messages, providing chat records, videos, and images as evidence to support my case. Eventually, ASUS acknowledged their mistake and provided me with a refurbished motherboard as a replacement. However, I did not receive any compensation for the trouble that I had gone through, despite paying top dollar for a new motherboard and ending up with a refurbished product.
I have loved ASUS since my first ROG Laptop.  I bought two laptops, three monitors, two GPUs and one motherboard over about 12 years.  However, every one of those products died in some way within a year.  The screen died on the first laptop, GPU on the second, motherboard failed next killing an entire system with it, first monitor tinted green permanently with everything except xbox one oddly enough, second monitor black screened, and most recently the TUF curved black screened within about 4 months.    I always assumed it was me up and until the TUF monitor when it occurred to me that all my ASUS stuff went the same way.  Then I realized, I've been building PCs for two decades and I've never had ANY other component break or fail on me.    I have just whitelisted ASUS in my head because I loved the brand and always heard good things about them, but finally realized their stuff just did not last.  I was going to get the ROG phone and was excited about the Ally, but it's impossible to overlook that track record.  I really just thought it was just me being really unfortunate.

I fully agree, i had stability issues with my 7950X on a ASUS TUF Gaming X670E Plus board as well - especially with running EXPO. It me over a month to solve the issue, by swapping out my CPU with a new one (seemed the memory controller got killed) and replaced the memory with a 2x32 GB Kit. The mainboard was not swapped, but i had tried dozens of ram configurations with/without EXPO and several BIOS updates until it settled. It was a real pain, but since then my system works perfectly. In addition i locked my PPT to 135W to not instantly get a 90 degrees hot CPU with a (Liquid Freezer II AIO), when the CPU is under load. Yes i am aware, i loose performance with that, but i canÂ´t negative offset the PBO curves - not even the slightest. No idea, if this is a ASUS/Mainboard problem or poor silicon quality.  But looking at the HWInfo i see that my CPU is constantly running with voltages over 1.4V, so i am little bit worried that i wear down my silicon more quickly. But i will only update the BIOS when it is not BETA and fully fixes the voltage problem...

I've felt similarly about ASUS for a few years now as well. They used to be my default choice for motherboards, GPUs, and laptops. In the last few years I've had an ASUS PSU fail, and a board that was DOA. Not a huge deal, both were returned to and refunded by the retailer, but not particularly confidence inspiring.  Most recently I bought a ROG Zephyrus m16 with a 3070ti, a relatively expensive offering in the ASUS ROG lineup. Within about a month of light usage (normally I run an external keyboard and hardly ever even touch the one on the laptop itself), one of the keycaps started popping off, the problem is that one of the tiny prongs that hold it to the key switch itself broke.   I reached out to ASUS support, explained the issue, explained that this is the computer I run my business from, and asked for them to send me a singular wafer-style keycap so that I can simply pop it on and fix the issue. The response from not only the phone rep that I was talking to, but also their supervisor, was that the laptop needs to be shipped to ASUS for a full RMA and repair process, the cost of which was TBD (everything still under warranty of course). I offered to send pictures, video of the issue, they did not budge. I'm sorry, but I don't think it's reasonable to have to ship over an otherwise fully functioning laptop over a 5 cent(?) key cap.

I've always kind of run ASUS and MSI boards of similar spec side by side, and my impression was always that the MSI boards are a little more reliable, but gamers like ASUS boards because they are better for overclocking and can be driven harder. That always gave me the feeling that ASUS likes pushing things to the edge, and since CPU manufacturers don't have the headroom for overclocking they once did, that mentality is leading them to be much riskier than before. They are used to the old days when you could reliably get another 10% or so out of any CPU you buy if you only jack up the voltage like crazy, and that's just not how it is anymore in sub-10nm world... now you really have to stick to the spec or bad things happen. In my view ASUS is the main one to blame, of course, but I can tell that CPU manufacturers increasing power draw and running CPUs with less headroom hasn't made things easier on them or any other board maker. Let's just say that some of the kind of components that used to be high-end are now pretty much a bare minimum for running a modern CPU, and what you need for overclocking more insane than ever. ASUS kind of backed themselves into a corner by being a "gamer/enthusiast" brand known for overclocking boards, and that's not a good place to be in 2023.
i love the honesty Jay, Asus will no longer have my backing when i build people gaming rigs and always went with Asus from now on that will never happen again!

I had it for 5 days before it started to malfunction on me. And as bad as the quality control on the laptop was, the customer service was so much worse. I played phone tag with their delartments when I initially wanted them to fix the laptop. They told me NewEgg was responsible for the warranty but then when I spoke with NewEgg they told me that ASUS was responsible but actually had receipts to backup that claim. All of these back and forth phone calls took over a week to fulfill but eventually ASUS reluctantly took responsibility.   They said that the repairs could take anywhere from 2 to 4 weeks. That was too long so I said I would rather take it to a local repair shop but they said that would void the warranty. So with the proposition of a 2 week plus repair schedule I debated on wherher or not it was worth it. It was day 21 after initially receiving it that I decided I would rather refund it. I lost a little bit of money on the shipping costs but otherwise got a full refund.   Probably the only thing ASUS was competent at was streamlining the return policy. Which, after doing some independent research, i found out that ASUS' quality control and incompetent customer service were far worse for manu other people. It's tolerable yo have poor quality control if the customer service is stellar and if the quality control is great then I frankly wouldnt need customed services' help anyway... But to be incompetent in both areas is reason for concern. They lost my business due to how long and draw out that whole process was and how they fought with me to not have to fix the laptop they sent me.  The silver lining though is that the laptop I got instead of the ASUS junk was the Lenovo Legion 7, which is perfect for all my needs. It runs everything I throw at it on max settings, the heating is manageable, its lightweight, it looks better and it shipped without any problems and is still running just as strong as the day I got it. Lenovo is much more reliable than ASUS is these days. And Acer isn't too bad either if Lenovo is out of your price range. I have experience with both and they are great laltop makers.

Under Australian consumer law their little blurb that say's "we are not responsible for damage" blah blah blah means less than nothing. Our laws even say they would be responsible for the CPU too. The website for our laws gives a nice easy example, you buy a washing machine, the washing machine leaks all over your carpet, the company who made the machine is responsible for the carpet, any Australians who have had problems with an ASUS board keep this in mind, and in emails just mention Australian consumer law and they should be a lot more helpful.

Thank you so much Jay. I've been building my own PCs over a period of 30 years and this generation of hardware has been the absolute worst for quality control and RMAs. I did an upgrade over the '22 holidays and I'm still dealing with the fallout of defective products. My Zotac 4090 graphics card had a nasty subtle failure from Day 1 where it wasn't stable for some games and some benchmarks at factory default clocks until you heat soaked it on a compatible game for a few minutes, like an old beater car needing to be warmed up before it worked right. Getting to the point where I could spot and reliably duplicate the pattern was an incredible amount of effort and frustration.  My first Gigabyte motherboard bricked itself during a routine BIOS update and their recovery method failed. Fortunately I was just inside the return window - I returned that and got an Asus Z790-P PRIME WiFi Motherboard. It was NEVER stable and would BSOD itself constantly even though I tried two kinds of memory, including one from their qualified memory list, and wasn't even running XMP. It cost me $40 in shipping to RMA it and after weeks went by, Asus sent me back the same board claiming everything was fine and all they did was update my BIOS.   Here's the thing though. I had replaced the Asus motherboard with a high-end Gigabyte Aorus Master. That solved my motherboard problems and when I got a replacement 4090 from Zotac, my graphics card problems went away. So now I'm out $300+ on this Asus board and I'm constantly going back and forth with their customer service. I know this particular serial number is junk, so I can't even sell it at a loss in good conscience. I need them to send me a new replacement board so at least when I go to sell it and try to cut my losses, I'm not knowingly selling a defective board to someone.   Either way you slice it though, this has been six months of troubleshooting and customer service hell. Asus deserves a smackdown for this and the industry in general does too, just to a lesser extent. I can't blame anyone for throwing their hands up and buying a gaming console instead of putting up with this nonsense.

Yeah, I'm done with ASUS myself. I've had 4 motherboards for the price of 2.  My original AM1M-A was DOA, and as a 13 year old I had to literally play personal advocate fighting their team to RMA the board. Their team was royally disgusting telling me that cuz I was so young it was likely my fault it was dead. They eventually caved after I explained that it literally was tested by the store I bought it from and they said it was DOA.  My most recent ASUS board was the Tuf Gaming B550 Plus (WiFi). Both of the SOC VRM phases blew up. When I say phases, I mean the entirety of the SOC VRM blew up. Holes in the PCB, in the MOSFETS, under the inductors, with burn and scorch marks riddling the inductors. A white flash from the case, a bang loud enough to give me ringing in my ears, and an instant hard shutdown with no response or warning.  The SOC VRM explosion severally screwed my R5 3600X to the point where 2 DIMMs / channel (I.e. my 4x8GB kit for 32GB of RAM) cant even run 2133 JDEC timings without errors. It can't even run 1800 with JDEC 2133 timings.  Their customer support was useless then, fighting me like "Oh did you try this? Or that? It's probably a power supply issue", after I literally told them I had the store test both parts. The PSU was literally prestine.  Apparently the SOC VRM failed due to a series of internal shorts to power from the MOSFETS on the high side. So if they used any better of a MOSFET, my 3600X probably wouldn't be alive.
It's been several years since I bought an Asus product, be it a motherboard, graphics card, or whatever.  The most recent Asus board I bought was an X370 (now dead), and the most recent Asus graphics card was a GTX 1060 (given to my daughter years ago), both within a few months of their initial release.  So my no longer buying Asus is aligned with my no longer buying Bud Light -- can't stop buying now a thing I already stopped buying years ago.  I have one active Asus board (the X99 system on which I'm currently typing) and zero active Asus graphics cards, and it's going to stay that way.
Graphics card side in my country is exactly the same as  motherboard division in the US, plain garbage and treat (not to mention TRICK) users,resellers, and even distributors, like shiet. I've stopped using them for more than a year now, after more than 10 years of lotalty. This is the predictable result of a conservative-appointed federal judiciary stacked with Federalist Society judges interpreting our laws in favor of the rights of capital over the rights of consumers and labor.  Corporations' sole remaining legal incentive is to provide a return to shareholders by whatever means possible, which has led to a race to the bottom in QC, R&D, and customer support, the results of which are becoming evident not just in Asus' products but across the spectrum of industry.  Products have been continually getting shittier in quality for the last couple of decades while simultaneously getting more expensive in price, and meanwhile inflation-adjusted wages have been stagnant since the 1970s, because Americans are so thoroughly and passively brainwashed by culture war bullshit that they can't even see they've been voting against their own self-interest for fifty years running.

Has anyone noticed similar issues on Intel's platform? My wife has a 13600K on a Strix Z790-F and she's been having random crashing with XMP and AI Overclock enabled. Turning them off seems to fix the issue. Temperatures haven't seemed to be a problem at all, but I noticed the VCORE requesting 1.51 volts and actually getting 1.49 right before it crashed at least one of the times.  And friend of mine just built his very first system on a 13600K with the Strix Z690-F at my recommendation and is having the exact same issue.   It only happens in some CPU-intensive gaming scenarios and it's not a hard crash with a BSOD, It's a soft lock with a gray screen, or color bars, and an unresponsive keyboard and mouse, where the computer needs to be manually rebooted.  Seems reasonable to me that if ASUS is pushing it too hard on AMD's platforms, it might be a culture thing and bleed over into their Intel BIOS as well.

I went through 2 Z790-E Gaming Asus motherboards because them coming with messed up pins. the first one I got all the way home and found them and had to take it back to Micro Center the second one was pulled off the shelf at micro center took up to the check out where they let me check the pins right there in front of them and wouldn't you know it had messed up pins, so they went back and brought up 3 boxes of the same motherboard and they all were just fine but the fact that they had two asus mother boards on the shelf with messed up pins was shocking and now I'm having a lot of Q code problems with the one I ended up with.
I think everyone is over reacting. ASUS realizes there is a problem, and QUICKLY released a new bios which is obviously untested. A disclaimer is somewhat warranted until testing is finished. Also, the problem isn't with the over volting, the problem exists only when the motherboard hangs on post and issues a 01 code, where the resistor arrays don't get set properly because the board hung. Almost nobody will have an issue, and those that do, leave their boards in a "hang" state for too long which causes the CPU burn out.
Sounds like AMD is not the way to go.

He was on an early bios and wanted to gain some memory stability. So I instructed him to update his bios with their specific tool that they provide. I think its called EZflash, dont remember and dont care. I had him get the correct bios and we began the flashing process (through windows. They had a tool that would work that way ig.) Mid way through the patch, the whole system locked up, and never came back after hours of waiting. Eventually, we killed the system, and it would never post again. My dad had to spend another 120 bucks or more on a new Asrock x570 gaming board because that board decided to fail. In fairness to Asrock, me and my dad both use Asrock boards now. They have been WAY more reliable than expected. I will likely buy an asrock board when I move off of my 9900k. Official service center told me that they did diagnistics, cleaned it and changed thermal grease, but it was no any problems with graphics card.. Yeah, sure :/ I sent it to unofficial service. They replaced some coils but didn't remove noise completely (as they said). So, they apologized, that they can not fix problem completely (actually could, but repair price will be too high) and didn't charge money from me. And they found no new thermal grease inside and but found some dust - graphics card was not cleaned, like official service said.  But, when I tested graphics card at home I found that coil whine was almost gone. Few minutes of undervolting removed it completely. Nice ASUS. Official service center did nothing. Unofficial repaired it for free.

Not entirely related, but would like to add my 2 cents as well: Asus has been... somewhat "special" towards their windows-using customers lately. Their proprietary app, armoury crate & aura, is intrusive beyond ANYTHING I'd seen before - and that's including razer and even nvidia side apps. It comes pre-installed on asus laptops and is HEAVILY promoted to install instead of drivers for any ROG product. You got a keyboard and wanna download the drvivers? Don't touch their site and just let windows do it. Otherwise look through the download links carefully before installing their software which would most likely still get downloaded before you find the drivers page.  It's a suite of host programs designed to regulate your RGB and (supposedly) all the Asus products. And by "a suite" I mean you'll see a NUMBER of services, processes and registry markers installed with it. The RGB one(Aura) actually affects your performance a bit, strongarming quite a lot of cpu for some reason - even if you have 0 asus RGB products in your system at the time.  Want to uninstall it? Google "armoury crate uninstall". They have a FAQ on the official site telling you "well you COULD try to uninstall it manually, but honestly just find the support page(we won't provide a link here, on the same support site) and download the Armoury Crate & Aura UNINSTALLER TOOL." Which is a glorified name for a series of command line scripts that clean up your system of ALL the bloat this one program pumps into it. And trust me: that cmd.exe is gonna RUN for a bit until it's all gone.
To be fair, memory stability issues are a standard feature of AMD CPUs so you can't blame Anus (yes intentionally spelled it like that) for that one.

It just has to work as advertised, last as long as the software running on it, be a fair price, and be covered by a comprehensive warranty and support lifecycle plan. I always ran under 1.25v because it was widely known that running high soc voltages was dangerous. Igorâ€™s lab recommended a max of 1.45v. I think a ton of blame is also on AMD for making people beta test voltages that donâ€™t hurt the cpu and they probably only gave ASUS recommendations and not hard limits. I have a 9940x that I ran 1.275 vcore on that degraded and canâ€™t run faster than 4400 MHz. Is that Intel or asusâ€™ problem? No. It is part of the overclocking game. To be fair we donâ€™t even have 100% guarantee that the 1.3v +0.08 vdroop is safe 24-7 for 3 years either. AMD is just guessing. My 7950x canâ€™t even post 6000 Xmp at 1.25v without tuning the whole bios. I am not surprised they pushed the voltage to have the best memory overclocking because thatâ€™s what asus always does with rog boards and there was zero documentation this was unsafe. Iâ€™m also not surprised any beta bios has this language in it. Iâ€™m sure they will release a final bios eventually and before then just donâ€™t run expo and run less than 1.3v. Why is this hard? I'm honestly really happy to see this. I'm not happy that we're in this situation, but ASUS has just gotten worse and worse and worse and worse, year over year. It isn't just the motherboard division either, we've seen the worst issues there of course, but we've had issues with laptops(shout out to Hardware Unboxed holding their feet to the fire about the cooling vents on the TUF 15 a few gens ago; ASUS handled that situation HORRIBLY), we've had issues with half-baked monitors(Linus used one for, what, like 2 months or something before replacing it with an LG IIRC?), this is something systemic going on within the overall business structure no doubt. Just like 5 or 6 years ago they had a pretty damn bulletproof reputation, you could always go with ASUS if you wanted a brand that you could be confident would "just work" and wouldn't give you any problems. Now, my 1st gen Ryzen system started out with an ASUS board and was replaced with an ASRock board shortly after because I was a lil disgusted by how little ASUS gives you in the way of features & I/O on their budget offerings, ASRock offered a lot more board for the money, but luckily I haven't had to stop using ASUS for a product failure. Helps that I've largely chosen to stay away as more and more of these issues have revealed themselves though.    And this really sucks too when their actions are damaging other brands, like AMD in this latest instance. Even if AMD has nothing to do with the fault, it still puts that kernel in peoples minds that "...well, I'm probably likely to just have less issues if I just go Intel...", which is obviously a bit of a problem(and it's not like ASUS has exactly shown any 'equality' with their handling of AMD products; they were the first to sign up for Nvidia's 'GeForce Partner Program' a few years ago that would've really undermined Radeon after all). We can't have this, it's terrible for the market in more ways than just the obvious ones.
Hey EVGA here's a market sector you can step into and save us.

I think you are way overreacting so is everyone in the comments - I have built PCs since 286's, and while do I definitely agree that there is an issue with quality control, that issue is spread across the entire industry, companies are cutting corners, customer service is not what it used to be, and quality control is not what it used to be, I can go over a huge list of fuck-ups companies made in the tech industry, ASUS is definitely NOT alone.  I would definitely choose ASUS for build quality and stability hands down - I've used ASUS for so many years on systems that are on 24/7, some even used for heavy loads and editing, rendering, development, and I could never be happier.   There are MANY companies out there that fit the description in your video, in terms of warranties, fighting, bad support, etc..   As far as the inverted capacitor, well yeah that is unfortunate, but there are other big brands equally responsible.  There have been WRONG capacitor types and voltages used on Samsung Smart TVs, causing premature failure, the list goes on and on, once upon a time you could buy an appliance and it would last you for 30 years +, not anymore, so yeah   You might as well drop Intel too for their 1700 socket design, for the connector catching fire issues, etc.  Poor quality control is everywhere.   There are millions of systems being built on ASUS till this day without issues, and certainly will not stop using ASUS from your video - Having used many other boards, I will stick to ASUS for my motherboards and ASUS for my graphics cards.    I used EVGA before that, but unfortunately EVGA parted ways with NVIDIA.  I've had so many issues with other graphics card, never with ASUS, I've had issues with other boards, and the only failure I had with ASUS in ALL those builds I have made, is ONCE, a faulty BIOS, and board was replaced promptly.

The hero board runs around 265w once undervolted and Im hitting 82c max with 10min of R23 cooling with a 420mm aio where i would be getting around 89c to 92c on the msi boards, there must be some information that board manufacturers are receiving from Intel and AMD that are making them drastically overvolt the hell out of cpus, it can't be a coincidence that there all doing the same thing.

Nice
Way back Gigabyte was considering discarding their motherboard division because of the bad product quality. It was literally a choice between getting out of the business or double down and revise their complete motherboard product line. They chose the later and in a year they went from incredibly high to extremely low return rates. That was a long time ago and I can't vouch for their quality today.  A few years back ASRock had a very bad run. Their motherboards were crap and they black listed some reviewers who exposed just how bad they were. This last generation of their motherboards are actually pretty decent.  Point is manufacturers seem to have a problem keeping the quality constantly high. I want to blame bean counters as I hate those. Marketing departments are not much better, but they are often in cahoots with each other. The problem is that continually keeping quality high can build brand recognition and loyalty, but when it is mostly smaller volumes and aimed at enthusiasts adding more RGB, flashier heatsinks, and bold colors often give a higher ROI than spending a dollar more on components and software that works.  Once it get so bad that they are called out like this it's is quite likely that the engineering department will get both better design budgets and more resources for firmware development an quality assurance. But that will only last a few years, until the immediate management moves up the ladder or swap companies, then the circle repeats again.

My Asus A8N SLI Deluxe was simply the perfect board for the upcoming change from IDE / P-ATA to SATA III (the usual IDE / P-ATA ports and additionally 2x4 SATA ports, 4 of them were even RAID capable) and the first PCIe graphic cards. In addition incredible 10 USB 2.0 ports, 1 eSATA, 2x IEEE1394 FireWire and on top of that two 1 GbE LAN ports.  Simply perfect, despite the outstanding high price tag (here in Germany the board has cost at that time ~140â‚¬ / ~175US$ incl. sales taxes, while boards were normally traded for 60 to 80â‚¬, in the extreme case perhaps up to 100â‚¬ / 75 to 100US$ in the extreme case up to 125 US$ incl. sales taxes)! When it loaded on system startup, it auto checked for updates and if it found any it would - without notifying - cease to monitor system sensors until the update was applied.  It didnâ€™t tell me there were updates, or download them itselfâ€¦ it just checked and if they were availableâ€¦ stopped monitoring sensors.  This happened version after version. As it was in control of the AIO speed and pump, it nearly fried my system a few times as it stopped monitoring the temps.  I ditched the silly ASUS AIO and put on a big olâ€™ Noctua double stack and CPU temps have been rock solid since. Then, after continued full system crashes I pulled the cooler off the (ASUS) RTX 3090 to find that the thermal compound was only applied (poorly) to half of the GPU. Things like "the problem is that add-in card is not  approved'. But everything works just fine changing just the motherboard. The last time was... got a board that had problems that a card would not even be reconized as plugged into the PCIE slot (yea PCIE-1). The drug it out over a YEAR sending me a total of 3 boards all of which were other peoples returns.    First had been dropped on the corner bending the corner and cracking the board  Second seemed almost like an earlier prototype because while it had the same name, it was a bit different layout and parts used. It had a lot of dust from fans blowing, it had some kind of oily residue and most of the electrolytic caps had domed. They were going or had gone bad.  The 3rd was one that had had extreme cooling that from the condensate etched much of the traces on the back of the board under the cpu.   Had a very hard time even talking to them, Not responding to emails and spends hours on hold on the phone. At one point they said "we had a server crash and lost all our emails". Then thye said the board was now out of production and they didn't have any new boards to replace the new defective board. I pointed out that Newegg was still selling them....  I got a new boxed board, but.... I had picked that board because it supported ECC, but when I turned it on, memory check would failed. It also could not recognize the AMD CPU. I sent them the part number the old board called the cpu as well as all the numbers from the cpu and complained about ECC not working. (Was something they had done in the newer bios it had, I think). They responded "We have not technical support contact with AMD"...  WHAT!!!! How could then be making boards for AMD CPU's then??? And not a peep about ECC no longer working.  So I always tell everyone stay FAR away from anything with their name on it. And anyone who raves about how "great" they are, I say has no idea what they are talking about.

MSI has always treated me rite. Gigabyte used to do shady crap just like ASUS is now doing. ASROCK used to be known as the budget brand boards much like ECS Elitegroup. RMAing an ASUS motherboard or GPU has always met some sort of difficulty. It should be No Questions Asked when you RMA a defective component.  1 of the fans on my Asus RX580 8gb (DUAL-RX580-O8G) video card quit working about 2 weeks after I got it and it caused the memory to overheat. It started artifacting really bad by the time that I realized what had happened. It took almost 2 months of BS for ASUS to send me another card. Turns out that there was a bug in the firmware that it shipped with that allowed the card to run at full clock speed no matter how hot it got. And a design flaw in the dual fan design (both fans were wired together on a single 3 pin header) It could not detect that the fan directly above the die and memory had quit working.

"Asus does not give any warranties whether express or limited as to the sustainability compatibility or usability of the UEFI, its firmware, or its content. " this section does not mention the product or its hardware. it says no warranty on FIRMWARE. thats fine. *"*Except as provided in the product warranty and to the maximum extent permitted by law, Asus is not responsible for direct, special, incidental or consequential damages resulting from using this beta BIOS." lets rephrase: Asus is not responsible for [...] damages, EXCEPT AS PROVIDED IN WARRANTY and permitted by law" This section specifically excludes anything in the original product warranty and permitted by law. The product is still covered by its original warranty. Asus however will not provide any additional warranty on damages resulting from this BIOS. Example: if this BIOS caused your motherboard to damage your graphics card they would not warranty your graphics card, or corrupted your hard drive due to the use of this BIOS.  The exception of the original product warranty would have them warranty the motherboard . This is a nothing burger. your Product Warranty is fine. nowhere does it say VOIDS PRODUCT WARRANTY. it says the FIRMWARE has no warranty.

I remember when ASUS was not only cheap, but very feature competitive for the dollar even at the flagship level. The last few years they've had a bit of a price creep, but on top of that, the various motherboard lineups seem to have made the ASUS brand seem a bit less-so than before. For example the ROG Boards just seem grossly overpriced, while ProArt ends up sporting a lot of the peripheral/IO needs, while TUF seems "cheap" and more cut down compared to other options...  The warranty thing is pretty unacceptable. Don't post software onto the website if it voids the warranty. Especially if the board doesn't have BIOS Flashback (oh yeah, that's another feature that has disappeared from the inexpensive boards). Make that sort of thing require a support ticket, so that if provided to a customer for testing, it's not only warrantied, but they can get the product back for failure analysis as part of the troubleshooting flow!  In the past I would put up with ASUS's software (AiSuite usually being garbage) only because their BIOS Interface has otherwise been solid. To this day their BIOS Interface is still pretty good in my opinion... but Armoury Crate and support for older boards running newer operating systems with said tools is just garbage. My board for example supports the 5800X3D and Windows 11, but the last update for AiSuite 3 was a few years ago, and it's so old that various Anti-cheat programs block the drivers for it due to vulnerabilities. Armory crate just doesn't provide the same controls, and I've had to move to open source software to get Windows Fan/System Monitoring support.  ASUS has a lot of work to do it seems, especially if they're going to charge $1,000 for a board... That's worse than Apple pricing at this point.

My current rig I built a little over two years ago about 2-3 weeks before the chip shortage: Asus prime z490 p motherboard, I9 10850k, rtx 3070, 32gb ddr4-3200, 700w PSU, 1tb ssd, and a 2tb hard drive. I love this build! I built it with a plan to not need an upgrade for at least 3-5 more years.  With the issues facing newer generations, I've grown to understand that newer isn't always better. With the prices of everything these days, building a moderate to high end system can be out of reach for many people. That said, some may not be able to drop $700 or more on a very high end motherboard or on the latest CPUs/GPUs.   This leaves customers stuck between a rock and a hard place because you shouldn't go too cheap on PC components like power supplies. Cheaper components often skip out on quality and performance. They function great at first but fail after a short time. When they fail, they tend to kill  components connected to them as well like CPUs and GPUs. Ultimately costing much more than you expected to replace.

A few years back I got an ASUS WS board (as they made the best boards from my personal experiences). Installed a supported Xeon with the latest BIOS. Things were running fine set up Windows 10 it did some updates then asked me to reboot to install the updates.When the motherboard re-booted suddenly during POST the CPU just began to smoke!? I quickly shut the power off. After inspecting the source of the smoke I found a similar issue - the motherboard had sent such a high voltage/amperage to the CPU that the socket pins literally had spot welded to the CPU. I sent the board in for RMA to ASUS and they claimed "socket pins damaged no warranty" when I explained the issue they argued with me that their technician claims I personally damaged the pins. (Despite it having obviously melted pins/socket). And that was it. They sent the board back to me and I lost a $500 Xeon and a $500 motherboard.

The last one being my fourth one is in perfect condition no psychical damages what so ever and no coil wind. Is there a clean company out there?
Back in the dinosaur days of PC building (late 90s and early 2000s) Asus was generally a "gold standard" company, particularly with motherboards that performed well, were reliable, and with a very low out of the box failure rate.  I built systems for myself and for friends, the P4 and P5 series were generally good products.  Fast forward a decade or more, and I had a bunch of Asus stuff still working.  Then I bought a router / wireless (a maybe a 66u, I think it was) and it was trash.  Poor signal, horrible firmware, bugs galore, drop outs, you name it, it did it.   It was a disaster or epic proportions.   A couple of motherboard failures later, and I ended up replacing with MSI, who's AMD boards seem to work pretty well without major fireworks.    I recently had to replace the motherboard in my son's older AMD build because of an odd boot failure, and the only board I could get readily local market was an ASUS board.   It's working out okay, but it's not all that I would want it to be either.  Firmware will always be their failure point, that is for sure.   I am hoping it lasts out a couple of more years until next gen stuff is out and I can move him up properly.
I wonder how this bodes for their new ROG Ally devices. Will they actually support it? Will we hear about exploding Allies? Will there be nightmare RMA stories?
Really annoyed I went full ASUS for my AM5 build. I'm lucky that I only had my 7950X3D for two weeks before voltage limiting UEFI came out, but its still frustrating, especially after my 4090 Strix had to be RMA'd because the card would crash going into lower power states.
I ran a computer company from 1996-2006 before selling it and moving on. During that time, ASUS was the flagship and go-to brand we sold. Even years later it was still my top choice - until about 2 years ago. It was obvious then that their quality control was quickly declining. I had 5 (yes, 5!) defective ASUS monitors in a row - multiple dead pixels and display issues. I had a $1000 TRX40 board that died 1 week after use... and more. I gave up on them as a trustable brand. My Threadripper PRO system I recently built was an ASRock WRX80 Creator, and it's been perfect.
Such a bummer, Iâ€™ve always like asus products, I have the prime x570 and two laptops from them. But after these shitty moves I will definitely avoid them, probably indefinitely.

I have a X670E-I and has been nothing but hot garbage ðŸ—‘ï¸, I'm on bios 0822 because every bios since then crashes my expo , new bios comes out I update , enable expo ,does not post revert back to 0822 and has been this way
The random usb disconnects of usb devices are likely partly to blame on usb hubs. Unfortunately some manufacturers use usb 3.2 hubs for the back io instead of using the actual usb 3.2 ports that are integrated into the chipset. Msi for example does this. They use one or two 10gbit ports from the chipset and then use a four port hub for the back io. That is so stupid and reduces reliability, increases power consumption, latency and causing potential connection problems. USB 3 is much more vulnerable to inteference.
I regret buying the PG42UQ from Asus. They haven't released a new firmware since late November and even on the newest version this thing still has wake-up issues and Asus just doesn't give a shit about fixing it.

This is the second time today where honestly I wish tech reviewers would read the EULA. Every software you use BIOS, Drivers, etc has a AS-IS AS-Available with no warranty in it. It's standard  Software boiler plates stuff. It does not void hardware warranties due to defects and workmanship which is what the hardware warranty covers. Like Asus should be getting a lot flak for a lot of stuff the voltage being high to begin with etc but the BIOS having standard boiler EULA warning especially for a Beta Bios that while should not have been available to the public does make sense.
